headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
abstract: AMC Networks’ flagship channel, AMC, came back to Dish on Sunday in time for the second episode of the new season of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: The Man Who Sparked Bollywood’s Love of Foreign Locales
abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

headline: Outside India, Shankar Fascinated Generations of Fans
abstract: Coverage of Ravi Shankar in the New York Times spanned six decades.

headline: Review of Reviews: The Surface
abstract: Here is what other tech product reviewers thought of the Microsoft Surface.

headline: Oracle: Big Business Has Big Data Woes
abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: AT&T’s Biggest Problems Aren’t Emboldened Rivals, Chief Says
abstract: AT&T’s chief executive said that his biggest problem was not renewed competition from the likes of Sprint Nextel. Instead, he is focused on the need to improve the company’s network and the uncertainty over the country’s fiscal future

headline: Japanese Manufacturers Help Save Chip Maker Renesas
abstract: Some of Japan’s largest manufacturers are contributing to a $1.8 billion bailout of the struggling chip maker Renesas, a move that will give the government and the companies a 69 percent stake.

headline: HSBC’s Big Asset Sale in China
abstract: HSBC Holdings is selling its stake in Ping An Insurance. | CVC Capital Partners’ Formula One investment is jeopardized by a legal battle. | Elizabeth Warren, Wall Street’s least favorite senator-elect, may land an even more powerful role. | Henry M. Paulson Jr., a former Treasury secretary, writes about China in The New York Times.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Wall Street Leaders Peer Into Economic Gloom
abstract: At the Buttonwood Gathering, hosted by The Economist magazine, it was clear that executives were contending with a world that is not easy to figure out.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 6
abstract: News, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Rising Out-of-Pocket Health Costs
abstract: The average deductible for people who get health insurance through their employer has doubled over the past six years, according to an analysis from the Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline: Study Finds Amputating Damaged Limbs Improves Quality of Life
abstract: For some time, there has been anecdotal evidence that troops who had severe nerve, muscle or bone damage to an arm or leg were better off undergoing amputations rather than trying to keep the limb. Now there is hard data that seems to confirm that suspicion.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Saturday, Oct. 13
abstract: News, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Of Gas Masks and Gum: Wife During Wartime
abstract: A husband writes of his worry and pride as his wife covers the Gaza conflict.

headline: Low-Interest Government Loans to Help With Storm Home Damage
abstract: Loans from the S.B.A. can help fund repairs to your home that aren’t covered by insurance.

headline: NBC Quickly Renews 3 New Fall Series
abstract: The network, which has not had much success in prime time recently, took the opportunity to celebrate the early-season success of “Revolution,” a drama, and two comedies, “Go On” and “The New Normal.”

headline: After Accusations of Insider Trading, a Profession of Innocence
abstract: A Denver businessman arrested on Friday on insider trading charges e-mailed his family and friends over the weekend, proclaiming his innocence and comparing his plight to challenges faced by Nelson Mandela and Steven P. Jobs.

headline: Exxon to Buy Canadian Oil and Gas Company for $3.1 Billion
abstract: Exxon Mobil has agreed to buy Celtic Exploration for about $3.1 billion in cash and stock to expand its presence in the energy-rich shale formations of western Canada.

headline: China Slams ‘Cold War Mentality’ in U.S. Report
abstract: China struck back Tuesday at a bipartisan congressional report that says two leading Chinese telecom companies pose a potential national security threat to the United States. The House report also said growing economic espionage against the United States was being conducted or supported by the government in Beijing.

headline: An Australian First: Outing Sex Offenders
abstract: The state of Western Australia has opened its registry of sex offenders to the general public, and reaction has so far been mixed. Some attorneys’ groups say it invites vigilantism.

headline: Flickr Has the Opportunity to Become the Next Flickr
abstract: Yahoo on Wednesday announced a long-awaited update to Flickr’s mobile experience. So what’s next for one of the first photo-sharing services?

headline: The Internet Attack That Wasn’t
abstract: On Monday, a popular security blogger sent out an alert that the entire Web might be under attack. As it turned out, the Internet was just undergoing the digital version of a fire drill.

headline: Chinese Theaters to Get Rebates for Showing Chinese Movies
abstract: The move is aimed at reversing the trend of growing audiences for foreign films there, with a goal of pushing the market share of Chinese films in China to 50 percent.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: CNN’s Identity Crisis and ‘Downton Abbey’ in New York
abstract: Also, another “Two and a Half Men” star apologizes and the photo editor at The People’s Daily may get The Onion after all.

headline: Playing the ‘Talk About Giving’ Game With Your Family
abstract: A card game encourages families to talk about money, charity and values.

headline: Google Leapfrogs Microsoft in Market Value
abstract: To the checklist of signs that the technology industry has entered a “post-PC” era, add this: Google’s stock market value passed that of Microsoft’s for the first time on Monday.

headline: S.E.C. Weighs Suing Aletheia Manager
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into accusations of improper trading by Aletheia Research and Management, which has filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Digital Notes: The Rolling Stones App, and Sony’s Streaming Music Discount
abstract: The app, developed with the involvement of the members of the band, was released in time for the 50th anniversary tour. Music Unlimited, from Sony, is dropping its price in the face of competition.

headline: Success of Israel’s Iron Dome Renews Interest in Missile Defense Systems
abstract: Israeli citations of the Iron Dome’s shoot-down rate have generated renewed interest in missile defenses around the world, spurring discussions with several nations that may wish to purchase it.

headline: Which Turkey is Healthiest?
abstract: Is it dangerous for Turkey to bring religion back, or is it necessary as it seeks to become a leader of the Muslim world? Will making the country’s leadership more reflective of the public risk the freedoms for women, artists and gays?

headline: Devoted to Facial Yoga (Don’t Try This in Public)
abstract: Jewelry designer Ranjana Khan’s facial yoga exercises.

headline: Law Firms Mine San Francisco for Internet Start-Up Gold
abstract: San Francisco is attracting more law firms intent on getting in on the ground floor with start-ups that promise big financial rewards down the road.

headline: Davis Polk Starts Litigation Practice in Hong Kong
abstract: Davis Polk & Wardwell is forming a litigation practice in Hong Kong, highlighting the continued push by New York’s blue-chip corporate law firms into foreign financial centers.

headline: Brother’s All-in-One Printer Is a Small Idea
abstract: Brother claims its Business Smart series printer, the MFC-J4510DW, is the world’s smallest-depth all-in-one printer, copier and fax machine.

headline: Twinkies’ Shelf Life May Last a Little Longer
abstract: Even if a court grants Hostess Brands’ motion to liquidate, there is a good chance it will include the sale of Hostess’s intellectual property, including trademarks like Twinkie.

headline: Medicare Spending Isn’t Out of Control
abstract: Compared with spending by private health insurers, Medicare looks efficient and prudent, an economist writes.

headline: My 6 Biggest Complaints About Business Travel
abstract: Does it really have to be so hard to find an electrical outlet?

headline: Sneak Peeks Into New Book on Goldman Sachs
abstract: The book by Greg Smith, a former employee of Goldman Sachs, isn’t scheduled to be released until Monday. But some details are already coming to light.

headline: Image of the Day: Oct. 12
abstract: A Border Security Force soldier at the India-Pakistan border post at Suchetgarh in Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Monday Reading: Deep Powder, Without Deep Pockets
abstract: Deep powder without deep pockets, how my smartphone emptied my wallet, new taxes take effect to fund health law and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Big Audience Tuned In to NBC for Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: An average of 22.4 million viewers were watching NBC’s coverage of the Macy’s parade at any given time between 9 a.m. and noon, more than in any year since 2001.

headline: Riverbed Technology to Buy Opnet for $993 Million
abstract: Riverbed Technology said on Monday that it planned to buy Opnet Technologies for $993.3 million in cash and stock, bolstering its business in optimizing software on corporate networks.

headline: Is Paying to Message Strangers a New Texting Business?
abstract: Cellphone carriers are making less money from text messages thanks to free messaging services offered by Facebook, Apple and other tech companies. But now Facebook is testing whether it can make some money by charging people to send messages to strangers.

headline: Sachin Was Us, and We Were Sachin
abstract: Sachin Tendulkar’s retirement from one-day cricket marks the end of an era for many Indian cricket fans.

headline: News Roundup: In Afghanistan, Reporting on Progress and Recalling the Soviet Invasion
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan the same week the Pentagon released a bleak report finding that Afghan forces still need assistance.

headline: ‘Fragile’ Australian Radio Hosts Get Counseling After Nurse’s Death
abstract: Anger continued to swirl around a hoax call made to a London hospital by two Australian radio hosts who talked their way past a nurse to get a medical update on Kate Middleton. Three days later, the nurse was found dead in an apparent suicide. But some Australians are also defending the hosts, who are said to be “shattered” by the uproar.

headline: An ‘Oppressive’ Regime Limits Free Speech in India, Civil Liberties Expert Says
abstract: The current government has a poor record on free speech, lawyer says, and the media is lionizing polarizing figures.

headline: HSBC in Record Settlement
abstract: HSBC agrees to a $1.92 billion settlement in a money laundering inquiry. | Britain arrests three men in connection with the manipulation of interest rates. | The Treasury sells its remaining shares in A.I.G. | British and American regulators are working together on ways to address the “too big to fail” problem of global banks.

headline: Siemens to Buy Rail Firm for $2.9 Billion
abstract: Siemens, Germany’s largest diversified industrial group, has agreed to buy the rail signaling business of the British company Invensys for $2.9 billion.

headline: For Clinton and Marie Claire, Much Ado About Whining
abstract: Comments by the secretary of state about her dislike of whining were interpreted, incorrectly, as referring to her former top policy adviser, Anne-Marie Slaughter.

headline: Candidates Spar Sharply Over China
abstract: Foreign policy issues provoked two of the sharpest moments of the second debate between President Obama and Mitt Romney. They clashed over the attack that killed four Americans in Libya, and there was a testy exchange about trade policy toward China.

headline: Can You Be English if You Don’t Speak English?
abstract: The leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party wants to ensure new immigrants learn English. His remarks are seen as a repositioning of policy on the issue of immigration. But do language skills matter that much in a multicultural society?

headline: Enforcement of India’s Internet Law to Be Revised
abstract: The controversial law remains unchanged.

headline: For Dell, Consolidation Is Innovation
abstract: Dell just announced a unified system of servers, storage, networking and software that employs technology from several of the companies it has purchased in the last few years. Having so many new products, the company argues, saves it from supporting legacy businesses with its R.&D.

headline: Deutsche Bank Says Report That It Hid Losses Lacks Merit
abstract: Deutsche Bank, the big German lender, said claims made by whistle-blowers that it had hidden $12 billion in losses during the financial crisis had been investigated previously and found to be without merit.

headline: RIM Promises to Reveal BlackBerry 10 on Jan. 30
abstract: Research In Motion said on Monday that it would display a new line of phones on Jan. 30, a move it hopes will revive its BlackBerry brand.

headline: Brontë Quiz: Cathy Dies. Then What?
abstract: The latest film version of “Wuthering Heights” stops well before the novel’s story has been told, as do many of its predecessors. A scholar takes exception: “We’ve turned it into a romance, because that suits us,’’ she says.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 13
abstract: Missile fire in Syria; circumcision in Germany; natural gas off Cyprus; and outsider art in Paris.

headline: Why I’m Looking for a New Bank
abstract: Here is what I’m looking for: a bank with convenient branches that is big enough to have excellent technology (A.T.M.’s and Web site) and good security.

headline: Chancellor Merkel’s Chance to Push Russia
abstract: The Petersburg Dialogue was set up to bring together a cross section of Russian society and encourage the country’s transition to democracy. It hasn’t worked that way.

headline: Sun Life to Sell U.S. Annuity Business for $1.35 Billion
abstract: Sun Life Financial, Canada’s third-largest life insurance company, announced a deal to sell its annuity and some life insurance businesses in the United States to a company whose owners include Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Store-Branded Gift Cards Carry Fewer Fees
abstract: A Bankrate study finds that gift cards from specific stores have fewer fees than general purpose cards that can be used at any store that accepts Visa, MasterCard or American Express.

headline: Apollo Turns a Profit as Portfolios Rise
abstract: Apollo Global Management is the latest private equity firm to prove that the third quarter was a boon to the industry, swinging to a profit from the same time last year as the value of its holdings improved.

headline: The Debt Limit Is the Real Fiscal Cliff
abstract: If the Republican leadership fails to negotiate in good faith over the ceiling on federal debt, President Obama should look to extraordinary powers to stabilize the nation’s outlook, an economist writes.

headline: Happy Gandhi Jayanti
abstract: Remembering Mahatma Gandhi on his birthday.

headline: From the Battlefields of Iraq to a Fight in Congo’s National Parks
abstract: William Coppeler, a veteran of Iraq, is working to help protect gorillas and other wildlife in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: A Conversation With: India’s Chief Climate Change Negotiator
abstract: Despite Hurricane Sandy, little change in Western attitudes to climate change at Doha talks.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 26
abstract: Narendra Modi sworn in as Gujarat’s chief minister for the fourth time.

headline: Lessons in Credit, on a Micro Level
abstract: The High Water Women Foundation, which was founded in 2005 by senior women in the hedge fund industry, holds financial literacy classes, focusing on lower-income communities.

headline: India and China Deepen Economic Ties
abstract: Trade between the sometimes hostile neighbors has skyrocketed, and $5.2 billion in new deals announced on Monday.

headline: What President Obama or President Romney Would Mean for the World
abstract: Citizens in China, Egypt, France, South Africa and Brazil on Obama vs. Romney — and The New York Times’s Susan Chira on what the outcome of the election will mean for U.S. relations with China and Syria.

headline: Family Treasures and the Secrets They Unlock
abstract: The writer is seeking a treasure, a bronze menorah, that she hopes will tell of the drama of generations of her family. Can discovering or retrieving such an object resolve a family mystery? Tell us your family stories of objects, lost or found.

headline: China’s Changing of the Guard: The Rise of Xi
abstract: The New York Times’s Beijing bureau correspondents on what the 18th Party Congress means for China’s relations with the United States, Japan and the world.

headline: A Landslide for Obama (If the World Got to Vote)
abstract: A new poll for the BBC World Service finds 20 of 21 countries favoring President Barack Obama in the upcoming election. Only Pakistan went for Mitt Romney.

headline: Image of the day: Oct. 11
abstract: Bollywood actor Amitabh Bachchan celebrating his 70th birthday.

headline: An American-Made Business Model Has Less Success Overseas
abstract: With the slowdown in once-hot emerging markets, the tide is going out on foreign investing, baring all of the problems and issues associated with global deal-making.

headline: ‘Dirty Jobs’ Comes to an End on Discovery
abstract: The show is the second reality TV pioneer to be shelved by Discovery this month. The channel confirmed last Friday that it had canceled “American Chopper,” the series about father and son bike-builders that had its start in 2002.

headline: Adele Leads Record Label to $67 Million Profit
abstract: The singer’s album, “21” — 2011’s top seller around the world, with more than 18 million in sales — was a rainmaker for her label, XL.

headline: General Electric to Buy Avio for $4.3 Billion
abstract: General Electric agreed on Friday to buy the Italian aerospace company Avio for $4.3 billion, acquiring a long-time partner in its jet engine business.

headline: How Much Homework Does It Take to Educate a Nation?
abstract: Which system is better: a European model that encourages equality, creativity and a healthy lifestyle or an Asian model that focuses on technical skills and concrete results? Students: Where would you rather study? Parents: Where would you want your children to be?

headline: China and India Top List of International Students Attending U.S. Colleges
abstract: China remains the No. 1 country of origin among international students at U.S. colleges, with 194,029 students in 2011-12. India, with 100,270 students, is still second.

headline: In China, New Leadership and New Style
abstract: The Chinese leadership is trying to shift perceptions and rebuild public confidence even though so far there have been no substantive policy changes.

headline: Daily Report: Sinofsky’s Abrasive Nature
abstract: According to several current and former Microsoft executives, several run-ins with other company leaders led to Steven Sinofsky’s departure, reports Nick Wingfield in The New York Times.

headline: Tuesday Reading: When Doctors Stop Taking Insurance
abstract: When doctors stop taking insurance, feeling the pressure to drink for work, American Express to refund $85 million and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Can Pujara Step Into Rahul Dravid’s Shoes?
abstract: An interview with Cheteshwar Pujara, 24, who has thrilled Indian cricket fans recently.

headline: Web Sites Offer Free Credit Monitoring
abstract: Two Web sites offer consumers free monitoring of credit report information, including alerts on new account openings and inquiries that may alert them to fraud.

headline: Putting a 13-Year-Old Child Safely on Facebook
abstract: For a child, getting their own Facebook is a sign that they are now officially a teenager, but they must be made aware of the consequences of their online actions. Here are some tips to help your child join the social network without regret.

headline: Tip of the Week: Posting Photos Quickly to Facebook in iOS 6
abstract: The new iOS 6 software for iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch offers speedier ways to post photos directly to a Facebook account.

headline: Q&A: Preventing Unintended Mobile Purchases
abstract: To prevent unwanted purchases (and unexpected bills), you can set your Android phone to require a PIN in order to purchase apps and games in the Google Play Store.

headline: In Goldman Programmer Case, a Way Around Double Jeopardy
abstract: There is a significant loophole in the double jeopardy clause — known as the “dual sovereignty” doctrine — that permits different governments to pursue the same case.

headline: As Labor Talks Collapse, Hostess Turns Out Lights
abstract: The bankrupt maker of cream-filled pastries like Twinkies and Ho Hos said on Friday that it planned to liquidate, a week after one of the company’s biggest unions went on strike to protest a labor contract.

headline: Friday Reading: Letting Patients Read the Doctor’s Notes
abstract: Entrepreneurs are starting up with fewer employees, American Airlines grounds planes to fix loose seats, and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Monday Reading: Traveling With Children With Special Needs
abstract: Traveling with children with special needs, doing your homework on school lunches, Google tests same-day delivery service and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Thursday Reading: Motorists Warned About Counterfeit Air Bags
abstract: Motorists warned about counterfeit air bags, three Alzheimer’s prevention drugs to be tested, getting off the work treadmill and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: When Free Stuff Leads You Astray
abstract: Free stuff — like a G.P.S. app — is not always best for your particular situation.

headline: Free Advice From Financial Planners in October
abstract: Four nonprofit groups are sponsoring free one-on-one sessions with financial planners in two dozen cities.

headline: Howard Stern to Return to ‘America’s Got Talent’
abstract: The network had hoped Mr. Stern, with his large following built during his long radio career, would spark some ratings lift for the series. That did not happen last year, but NBC executives said the addition of Mr. Stern most likely prevented a sharp falloff.

headline: India Hosts Both U.S. and Iran in Delhi (Again)
abstract: An awkward diplomatic dance in the nation’s capital highlights India’s global balancing act.

headline: Bal Thackeray and the Blood on the Congress Party’s Hands
abstract: The “secularism” of the Congress party has often meant granting equal opportunities to thugs of all hues to wreck normal life. Bal K. Thackeray, who died on Saturday, was a direct beneficiary of this complicity.

abstract: Cargill finds trouble in Japanese ‘love hotel’ deal. | Why Americans could pay higher taxes come January. | American Express to pay refunds over debt collection practices.

abstract: A 2011 study served as a foundation to a more recent Congressional Research Service report that drew Republican criticism.

headline: Q&A: Making Money From Flickr Photos
abstract: Photographers sharing pictures on Flickr can invite editors from the Getty Images photo archive to review — and possibly license — their work.

abstract: The $3.7 billion bid to privatize Nasdaq-listed and Shanghai-based Focus Media, a leveraged buyout backed by private equity and management, is the biggest deal in a rising wave of Chinese companies seeking to delist from American exchanges.

headline: 2 Senators Call for Greater Bank Capital Requirements
abstract: In a new letter to be sent to regulators on Wednesday, Senator Sherrod Brown, a Democrat, and Senator David Vitter, a Republican, argue for tougher rules for bank capital, the cushion that financial institutions must keep against losses.

headline: Fraser & Neave Rejects $1.1 Billion Bid for Hospitality Unit
abstract: Weeks after agreeing to sell its brewing unit to Heineken for $4.6 billion, the Singaporean conglomerate Fraser & Neave has rejected a $1.1 billion bid for its serviced-apartment business while its shareholders are weighing an outright takeover offer from a Thai billionaire.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Nov. 16
abstract: News, arts, fashion and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: ‘Too Big to Fail’ Remains Very Real
abstract: Despite declarations from the financial industry that the risk of “too big to fail” institutions has been removed, government subsidies make that a hollow claim, an economist writes.

headline: For Buffett, the Long Run Still Trumps the Quick Return
abstract: In New York to promote a new book about him, Warren E. Buffett lamented Wall Street, which promotes a trading culture over an investing culture.

headline: Regulator to Press for Financial Response Team for Disasters
abstract: Bart Chilton, a regulator at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, plans on Tuesday to urge financial firms and federal authorities to bolster coordination in the face of future calamities.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cyber Monday Deals and Samsung’s Chinese Suppliers
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes a debunking of a viral post about Facebook and copyright, a false report of an acquisition by Google and a company that benefited from the problems with Apple Maps.

headline: Ex-Trader Sentenced In Loss at UBS
abstract: Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader, was given a seven-year jail sentence after he was found guilty on two charges of fraud for actions that prompted a multibillion-dollar trading loss at the Swiss bank, though he was found not guilty on four counts of false accounting.

headline: Judging if Wiretaps Are Necessary
abstract: At a federal appeals court hearing on Thursday involving Raj Rajaratnam’s appeal of his convictions for conspiracy and insider trading, the critical issue will be whether the government established that it needed to use wiretaps because other avenues of investigation were not fruitful.

headline: Pay Wall Push: Why Newspapers Are Hopping Over the Picket Fence
abstract: Charging for content, long the scourge of the Internet, has become almost sexy. What’s ahead in the fight for paid readers.

headline: Home for the Holidays, or Not: Tell Us Your Stories
abstract: There is plenty of allure, challenge and excitement to living abroad, but those with a proclivity for homesickness can find themselves awash in it during the holiday season. Have you spent your holidays overseas, as a student, on a work assignment, or by choice? Where did you go? How did you celebrate? Tell us your stories. And tell us your stories of going back home too. We’ll post our favorites during these last weeks of 2012.

headline: The Big Loan Backing Freeport’s Energy Deals
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is the sole initial underwriter for a $9.5 billion loan facility to support Freeport-McMoRan’s takeovers of two oil and gas explorers, in a move that the firm has made something of a specialty.

headline: Up on the Roof, a Real-Life Farmville
abstract: Rooftop farms in some of the world’s most crowded cities, including Hong Kong, New York and Tokyo, are adding a bit of green to the gray. They are reconnecting city dwellers with nature, teaching consumers about homegrown food and offering a glimpse, perhaps, of a more secure and sustainable food supply.

headline: Q&A: Declining a Kindle’s Special Offers
abstract: The ads on Amazon’s “Kindle With Special Offers” models subsidize the purchase price of the e-reader, but you can turn them off if you pay.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Ellison’s Art Museums, and Foursquare From Mars
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes an iPhone dissection and analysis that you probably won’t want to try at home, Steve Jobs seemingly looking into the future from 1983 and Andreessen Horowitz’s investment in a rap lyrics site.

headline: A Legal Brawl in Mexico as Bond Buyers Look On
abstract: The outcome of a bankruptcy reorganization in Mexico could put a crimp in Mexican companies’ ability to sell corporate debt.

headline: ‘Community’ to Return From the Wilderness in February, NBC Announces
abstract: The sitcom with a cult following has been blowing in the wind for months now. The network plans a Thursday home for it, where there is a chance that good ratings could help it endure.

headline: Olympics Turmoil Can Be Solved With a Chat, Indian Official Says
abstract: Indian Olympic Association official plans to go to the international body to explain.

headline: Veterans Feel Anxiety, and Relief, After School Shooting
abstract: Adam Lanza, the gunman responsible for the shootings at a Connecticut school on Friday, never served in the military. That’s when the strange and selfish feeling struck me: one of relief.

headline: Fighting for Free Speech Online in India
abstract: A retired physics professor in Tamil Nadu, on the front lines of a growing battle.

headline: Local Restaurateurs Feed Wall Street’s Hungry Deal Makers
abstract: A stable of local restaurateurs are being periodically invited to set up shop at financial firms like Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse.

headline: The List That Big Banks Don’t Wish to Be On
abstract: The Financial Stability Board, a body that coordinates international bank regulations, has come out with its list of “systemically important” big banks. Of the 28 firms on the list, eight are from the United States.

headline: Chaplain With Traumatic Brain Injury Finds the Tables Turned
abstract: For Lt. Col. Richard Brunk, a former Army chaplain, two instances of traumatic brain injury from blasts in Iraq have tugged away at a mask of good cheer, The Times’s James Dao reported as part of The Hard Road Back series.

headline: Mapping the Path to Your Credit Report
abstract: Credit card and loan information will show up on your credit report, but some public records are more likely to be there than others.

headline: For Small Businesses, More Than Income Tax Rates Are at Stake in Deficit Talks
abstract: While most of the discussion about taxes is focused on the expiring Bush-era tax cuts, a host of other deductions and credits that directly affect small businesses are on the line — and on the table.

headline: A Conversation With: Singer Sukhwinder Singh
abstract: On the hit song “Jai Ho” from “Slumdog Millionaire,” his career and working with A. R. Rahman.

headline: Monday Reading: Travel Tips for Students, By a Student
abstract: Travel tips for students by a student, the afterlife of your frequent flier miles, how to freshen up a computer and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: More Safety Features for Amarnath Pilgrims
abstract: The journey to the Amarnath shrine, at 12,000 feet, has claimed many lives.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Royal Pregnancy, and Ailes’s Offer to Petraeus
abstract: The news that Kate Middleton is pregnant has already gotten the gears going among news media outlets; the head of Fox News conveyed a message to David H. Petraeus last year encouraging him to run for president; and, a book explores the new golden age of TV.

headline: Before Facebook Deal, Instagram’s Talks With Twitter
abstract: Instagram’s founders had talks with top Twitter executives as late as March, verbally agreeing to a price for the photo-sharing service, according to a New York Times report. | The American International Group is preparing to end its longtime association with the Asian insurer AIA Group. | Argentina is still fighting over defaulted bonds, but it’s at least getting a naval ship back. | Sidney Gilman, the Alzheimer’s researcher at the center of an insider trading case, lived a double life.

headline: Sinopec Strikes $2.5 Billion Deal With Total
abstract: Sinopec agreed on Monday to buy a stake in a Nigerian oil field from Total of France for $2.5 billion, the latest in a flurry of acquisitions by Chinese energy companies.

headline: Europe Ready to Send Military Trainers as Mali War Looms
abstract: Preparations are under way for an international effort to oust radical Islamists who control northern Mali. The European Union is ready to send military trainers to the West African state but Africans would do the fighting.

headline: 3 Unorthodox Ways to Solve Europe’s Debt Crisis
abstract: Solutions to Europe’s sovereign debt crisis are mostly tried and true. Here are three plans that aren’t bound by the policy makers’ current orthodoxy.

headline: What They Said: The Gujarat and Himachal Pradesh Elections
abstract: Politicians weigh in on the initial election results.

headline: The Math on the Romney-Ryan Tax Plan
abstract: Paul Ryan told an interviewer that the Republican tax plan would be “revenue neutral” but said he didn’t have time to explain the math. It is difficult to make it add up.

headline: In Goldman Sachs’s Retreat From I.P.O., a Signal to Investors
abstract: Goldman withdrew as the lead underwriter for the initial public offering of the Russian cellphone operator MegaFon, but the multibillion-dollar offering is hurtling forward nonetheless, highlighting a flawed system.

headline: E-Books Expand Their Potential With Serialized Fiction
abstract: Byliner, a digital publisher, and Amazon have delved into the genre in recent months, and a serialized novel will be available on Apple devices on Monday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama as Star in ‘SEAL Team Six’
abstract: Also, the BBC continues to take heat for a decision to cancel an investigative report into accusations of sexual abuse made against a longtime employee who died last year.

headline: AT&T to Increase Spending on a Big Network Expansion
abstract: AT&T said on Wednesday that it would increase spending on equipment and infrastructure for its phone and Internet services over the coming years, which should give customers stronger, more reliable service.

headline: For a New Generation, a New Literary Battle Over Jeffrey MacDonald’s Guilt
abstract: The author of “Fatal Vision,” Joe McGinniss, has issued an e-book, “Final Vision,” that responds to a new round of criticism. He has long been a target for arguing that Dr. MacDonald was rightfully convicted for murdering his wife and daughters.

headline: Hedge Funds Stride the Stage of World Affairs
abstract: With the right idea and enough financial firepower, hedge fund investors can exert significant political and economic influence — even to the point of setting monetary policy.

headline: Why Everyone Wants to Fire the Founder
abstract: Firing the founder is often part of a strategy to flip the company to a new set of investors.

headline: Julius Baer to Buy Stake in Italian Money Manager
abstract: The Swiss bank Julius Baer has agreed to buy a 19.9 percent stake in Kairos Investment Management of Italy for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Another ‘Nail House’ in China Gets Hammered
abstract: After long resistance by a Chinese duck farmer and his wife, their “nail house” is demolished.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Look at Some Popular iPhone Apps
abstract: The most popular apps in the Apple store are popular for a reason. Here are three of the best for a dollar each.

headline: In Insider Trading Case, Drawing In David Ganek
abstract: Anthony Chiasson, a co-founder of Level Global, is trying to show that his more prominent partner, David Ganek, who has not been accused of wrongdoing, traded in the same stocks during the same periods.

headline: 2 More Officials Plan to Leave the S.E.C.
abstract: Two top officials — Mark D. Cahn, the general counsel, and Robert W. Cook, the director of trading and markets — plan to leave the agency.

headline: Nomura Ekes Out a Profit After a Scandal
abstract: Nomura posted net profit of 2.8 billion yen ($35 million) in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with a 46.1 billion yen loss for the period a year earlier.

headline: Milken’s Past Invoked in Gupta Sentencing
abstract: More than two decades after pleading guilty to securities fraud, Michael Milken continues to loom large as a symbol in the world of white-collar crime.

headline: Ally Repays Last of Debt Borrowed Under F.D.I.C. Guarantee
abstract: Ally Financial, the former G.M.A.C., said Wednesday that it had repaid $4.5 billion in debt that was guaranteed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels

headline: The Man Who Sparked Bollywood’s Love of Foreign Locales
abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

abstract: Coverage of Ravi Shankar in the New York Times spanned six decades.

headline: Review of Reviews: The Surface
abstract: Here is what other tech product reviewers thought of the Microsoft Surface.

headline: Oracle: Big Business Has Big Data Woes
abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: CNN to Interview Reddit’s Violentacrez: A Troll Comes Out From Under the Bridge
abstract: Violentacrez, the moderator of several highly controversial forums on Reddit, was outed on Gawker and fired from his job, and he will now sit for an interview with CNN.

headline: How to Bypass Instagram’s Twitter Barrier
abstract: After Instagram began blocking its photos from appearing on Twitter, here are some tricks to get past the Instagram barrier.

headline: Home for the Holidays: When Your Native Country Is the One That Feels ‘Foreign’
abstract: Moving the entourage that is my family is no small logistical feat. And I have to marvel at how my role — once the bachelor whose only worry was finding a window seat — has changed.

headline: Does India Still Need Khap Panchayats?
abstract: The age-old, unelected villages councils, are an integral part of village life in Haryana, experts say.

headline: How to Buy Art When Traveling Abroad
abstract: “The art world, really more than any other world I can think of, is a global village,” says Barbara Gladstone, owner of the Gladstone Gallery.

headline: Breakfast Meeting: The Power of TV Debates
abstract: Also, a guide to how the campaigns will try to shape perceptions after Tuesday’s debate, and concern about the moderator, Candy Crowley of CNN.

headline: Fed Official Says Monetary Steps Were Too Timid
abstract: “With the benefit of hindsight, monetary policy needed to be still more aggressive,” William C. Dudley, vice chairman of the Fed’s policy-making committee, says in a speech.

abstract: Three travel tips to navigate the aftereffects of Hurricane Sandy, a possible insurance blow for flood victims, wireless charging for the Leaf and Volt and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

Penney to Apple makes little sense, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes.

headline: Blackstone Enters $1.2 Billion Energy Partnership
abstract: The alternative investment giant has announced a partnership with the oil producer LLOG Exploration to invest a combined $1.2 billion in offshore assets in the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: To ensure that award voters see its movie before the early onset of Oscar voting, Universal Pictures is holding a series of screenings of “Les Misérables” in Los Angeles and New York.

abstract: The British bank has earmarked an additional £700 million to compensate clients who were inappropriately sold payment protection insurance.

abstract: In the coming months, Twitter plans to update its mobile applications to introduce photo filters that could compete with Instagram, according to people who work at the company.

abstract: Our most read and commented on Europe posts ranged from Great Power Politics and the future of European Construction to well, British Royal tops and bottoms.

headline: Newswallah:Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Few More Must-Try Apps for iPad
abstract: A few more apps to help new iPad owners make the most of their tablet PCs, whether they have an iPad 4 or Mini.

headline: R.B.S. Raises $1.3 Billion in Listing of Insurance Unit
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland, majority owned by the British government, has raised $1.3 billion through the initial public offering of its insurance unit Direct Line.

abstract: Srinagar-Leh National Highway closed following heavy snowfall in the Kashmir valley.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Web Tools Cut Wait Time at Doctor’s Office
abstract: Web tools can reduce wait time at the doctor’s office, airlines likely to match Southwest’s fare increase, F.D.A. warns of other risks from tainted drugs and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: Carl Richards (and Alice, the one from Wonderland) offer a guide to setting (and changing) your financial goals.

abstract: No matter how good your robot costume looks, your movements still sound like clattering plastic and cardboard. Mega Stomp Panic adds sound effects to your costume synchronized to your movement.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Foxconn Photos, and Amazon Chief’s Advice

Wednesday’s selection includes a mobile first advocate addressing some of the difficulties of growth in the mobile sphere, a list of the year’s most popular musicians in terms of blog posts and a look at the top earners in mobile apps.

headline: Buy, Sell, Adopt: Child Trafficking in China

headline: Looking Ahead to Civil and Criminal Cases to Come
abstract: If recent cases serve as a guide, too many loopholes in the system allow white-collar fraud to go undetected.

abstract: At one point during an exchange, the CNN host interrupted the executive director of the Gun Owners of America to ask: “You’re an unbelievably stupid man, aren’t you?”

headline: How Local Tax Rates Affect High-Income Professionals
abstract: What impact do high state and local taxes have on Wall Street executives and fund managers? The example of professional athletes offers some insights.

abstract: After being let go by Goldman Sachs, Matthew Marshall Taylor was hired by Morgan Stanley. On Thursday, the C.F.T.C. filed an enforcement action against the trader.

abstract: The event, which takes a cue from the “upfronts” for TV, will be administered by the Interactive Advertising Bureau, reducing the role of the digital advertising agency Digitas.

headline: A Dive Into Our Archives: Buchwald Meets Cousteau
abstract: The year: 1956. The subject: Prince Rainier’s approaching wedding to Grace Kelly. The quote: “As you know, a woman wants to be the sole interest of her husband,” said Jacques-Yves Cousteau to Art Buchwald. “She is jealous of his hobbies.” The hobby in question? Read on.

headline: A Conversation With: K. Taraka Rama Rao, Telangana leader
abstract: The leader fighting for statehood for Telangana, on being politically ignored by the Congress Party, lack of unity among regional parties, Naxalism, and more.

Berger, the plaintiffs lawyer, isn’t celebrating his six major securities class-action settlements.

abstract: The anonymous man had told the gossip Web site TMZ that he had had a sexual relationship with Kevin Clash, who voices the popular character Elmo, while he was under age.

abstract: Consumers would do well to pay more attention to what they pay in bank fees and to consider the more consumer-friendly approach of credit unions, an economist writes.

abstract: When a Manhattan man found out that Time Warner Cable would begin charging a $4 monthly rental fee to use its cable modem, he started researching modems he could buy to avoid paying the fee. But he soon stumbled across an odd inconsistency in the way the company is applying the fee.

abstract: The rules on real estate mortgage investment conduits are designed to prevent operating companies from avoiding corporate tax. Banks and other financial institutions that originate mortgages should pay that tax. Passive conduits should not.

abstract: Now that Xstrata’s board has backed Glencore International’s bid, it’s up to shareholders to decide. | Barron’s makes a bullish case for Goldman Sachs. | Leon Cooperman takes aim at President Obama’s rhetoric in a widely circulated letter. | David Rubenstein at Duke University, his alma mater.

abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: The Future, as Imagined by Google
abstract: At Google’s Zeitgeist conference, its chairman, Eric E. Schmidt, described a long-term future in which life is managed by robots — and one a little bit closer to reality, in which billions more people can get access to information with new devices and connectivity.

headline: One on One: Google Android Director on Nexus Strategy
abstract: Google recently introduced Nexus devices in small, medium and large: a phone, an upgraded seven-inch tablet and a 10-inch tablet. That puts Google in even more direct competition with Apple. In an interview, John Lagerling, director of business development for Android, shares his views on Google’s Nexus strategy.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Why Afternoon Exercise May Be Best
abstract: Why afternoon exercise may be best, New York ski areas offer $10 lift tickets, gift ideas for frugal travelers and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: The bank reported $4.9 billion in profit for the third quarter, mostly because of a big increase in its mortgage business.

abstract: The purchase by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt of the culinary portfolio of John Wiley & Sons, as well as its reference books, means acquiring the all-American Betty Crocker cookbook series, among other assets.

abstract: A parliamentary commission investigating recent banking scandals in Britain heard testimony from Paul Volcker, who pushed for tighter banking rules.

headline: YogaFit Decides Its Web Site Needs to Shape Up
abstract: But finding a Web design and development firm has been a challenge.

headline: Jefferies Posts $71.6 Million Profit in 4th Quarter
abstract: The investment bank said on Tuesday that it earned about $71.6 million in profit for the fourth quarter, up 48 percent from the same time a year ago as its core businesses showed marked improvement.

headline: Vettel Wins Second Straight, and Kobayashi Shines at Home
abstract: Fernando Alonso of Ferrari crashed out of the Japanese Grand Prix and his main challengers all scored points, leaving the winner, Sebastian Vettel of Red Bull, just four points behind Alonso in the driver championships. But the star of the day was the Japanese driver Kamui Kobayashi, who finished third in his Sauber.

headline: In Soccer as in Life, Will a Resurgent Germany Dominate a Weakened Europe?
abstract: Germany’s rise to dominate Europe on the economic front is clear, but the IHT’s Nick Kulish reports that German might extends to an even more important realm: soccer.

headline: Secrets of High Credit Scorers
abstract: People with high FICO credit scores aren’t perfect but they pay their bills on time, an analysis from myFico says.

headline: Investors’ Billion-Dollar Fraud Fighter
abstract: With last month’s Bank of America settlement, Max Berger has been responsible for six securities class-action settlements of more than $1 billion.

headline: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries
abstract: The country added jobs in November, the 26th consecutive month of gains: 146,000 nonfarm payroll jobs, to be more precise. But employment still has a long way to go before returning to its prerecession level.

headline: A Conversation With: Chief Economic Adviser Raghuram G. Rajan
abstract: Mr. Rajan wants to strengthen financial institutions, shift people from agriculture to service and industry, and improve upon his Hindi language skills.

abstract: The site of the senseless killing of schoolchildren is now a base of operations for TV news; in Puerto Rico, a free-speaking puppet with a TV show may have crossed a line; and an escapee from tech blogging returns on his own terms.

headline: Daily Report: Texting Business Is in Tumult
abstract: Smartphone apps that use the Internet, rather than cell networks, to send text messages among users, often free of charge, are pushing wireless providers to change their pricing models.

headline: On Instagram, 10 Photos a Second of #sandy
abstract: As Hurricane Sandy churns its way through the Atlantic, those in its path are turning to their smartphones, and specifically Instagram, to document and share their experiences. Kevin Systrom, founder and chief executive of Instagram, said 10 pictures a second tagged with “sandy” were flowing through the service.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker to Sell Hardware and Home Unit for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Stanley Black & Decker agreed on Tuesday to sell its hardware and home improvement unit to Spectrum Brands, the maker of Rayovac batteries and George Foreman grills, for $1.4 billion in cash, as it worked to whittle down its product portfolio.

headline: A Counterculture Totem to Return as a Leaner Magazine
abstract: The influential music magazine Arthur, which in its earlier incarnation had a circulation of 40,000 as a free publication, will return on newsprint in December at a cost of $5 an issue.

headline: Apple Expected to Unveil Smaller iPad Oct. 23
abstract: Apple sent invitations on Tuesday to members of the media for an event next week where it is expected to introduce a smaller version of the iPad.

headline: Long After War, Moral Questions Linger
abstract: An Army doctor during the Vietnam War says his most difficult duty was navigating moral dilemmas that never seemed to have correct answers.

headline: Banks Seek a Shield in Mortgage Rules
abstract: As mortgage rules under the Dodd-Frank Act are finished, banks and policy makers want legal protections against lawsuits, while others worry that this will deny borrowers a critical safeguard.

headline: French Downgrade Focuses on Failure to Compete
abstract: Moody’s has downgraded France’s valued AAA sovereign debt rating. The bad news for President Hollande comes on the heels of what was seen as an irksome piece of France-bashing by The Economist magazine.

headline: Daily Report: College of the Future May Be on the Internet
abstract: Tamar Lewin reports on massive open online courses, MOOCs, in Tuesday’s New York Times. These are college-level courses free to anyone with an Internet connection, offered by elite universities that have joined forces with private companies.

headline: Oh Kolkata! My Second Goodbye to Home
abstract: With so much changing in the rest of India, Kolkata’s constancy feels like a regression.

headline: ‘Fright Night’ for Cameron on European Budget
abstract: Hostilities in the European Union over the size of its budget spilled into the British parliament where rebel legislators handed Prime Minister David Cameron a Halloween night defeat.

headline: British Commission Says Bank Reforms Don’t Go Far Enough
abstract: A recommendation for periodic reviews of whether banks are adhering to the rules — referred to as electrifying the ring-fence protections.

headline: At a Banking Gala, Chatter Is About Citi’s New C.E.O.
abstract: The 10th-annual Most Powerful Women in Banking gala focused less on the leadership change atop Citigroup than on the state of women in the financial industry.

headline: $3.13 Billion Specialty Insurance Deal
abstract: The Markel Corporation, a specialty insurer, on Wednesday said it had agreed to acquire a rival, Alterra Capital, for $3.13 billion.

headline: Netflix Reaches Deal to Show New Disney Films in 2016
abstract: Walt Disney Studios said on Tuesday that it had completed a deal to show films from its Disney, Pixar, Marvel and Lucasfilm banners on Netflix, the first time that one of Hollywood’s Big Six studios has chosen Web streaming over pay television.

headline: Presidential Debate Drew More Than 70 Million Viewers
abstract: Nielsen, a television measurement company, said that 67.2 million viewers watched on television, but its total did not count any of the millions of people who had access to the debate on computers, tablets or phones.

headline: Britain Examines 4,000 HSBC Accounts in a Tax Haven
abstract: The British tax authorities said Friday that they were investigating HSBC accounts on the British island of Jersey.

headline: Candidates Debate Rise of China; China Debates Reform
abstract: The presidential candidates are set to debate the rise of China tonight, but China’s next leader may wish his nation’s economy were the juggernaut many Americans think it is.

headline: Fed Governor Suggests Congress Weigh Laws to Limit Bank Size
abstract: In a wide-ranging speech at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, Daniel K. Tarullo, of the Fed’s board of governors, said Congress could set limits to ensure that institutions aren’t “too big to fail.”

headline: Motorola Maxxes Out, This Time in HD
abstract: Motorola’s flagship Droid RAZR Maxx has been updated and reissued as the Droid RAZR Maxx HD, as the company continues to aim for the iPhone’s soft spots.

headline: With Bal Thackeray on Life Support, Mumbai Braces for Violence
abstract: The Shiv Sena leader’s death could spark riots among his supporters, many fear.

headline: U.S. colleges courting Chinese students
abstract: Colleges, education agents and counselors are flocking to Asia. Some are legitimate and some are not. Here are some tips on how to tell the difference.

headline: Another Star Lashes Out, and ‘Two and a Half Men’ Keeps Cruising
abstract: Unlike the Charlie Sheen meltdown, the criticisms of the show by the actor Angus T. Jones — he called it “filth” in a video — are not expected to threaten its future. On Tuesday night, he issued an apology.

headline: A Start-Up Sees an Opportunity in Diabetes Prevention
abstract: Omada Health, a San Francisco start-up, is offering a diabetes prevention program to the general public. The potential market is certainly large, since an estimated 79 million Americans are at high risk of developing diabetes.

headline: After Bailout, Giants Dominate the Mortgage Business
abstract: Wells Fargo and JPMorgan were allowed to gobble up small and weak competitors in the mortgage business, and now their biggest threats, Citigroup and Bank of America, are pulling out.

headline: Daily Report: Sean Parker’s Start-Up Struggles
abstract: Airtime, the much-hyped video chat site created by Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, the two behind the music sharing service Napster, has turned out to be far from a sure thing. The site is just four months old, and the staff is tweaking its features to make it more appealing. So far, though, Airtime’s traffic appears to be little more than a trickle.

headline: Kia Becomes a Time Machine in New Ads With Blake Griffin
abstract: The campaign, which begins Tuesday and will include five different ads, taps two areas that Kia uses to reach its target audience: sports and music.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Nov. 19
abstract: News, education, arts and sports from today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: You’re Probably One of Two Kinds of Shoppers
abstract: If you’re a hard-core shopper, you’re not going to want to spend any time in the stores with people like Carl Richards, the artist-in-residence at the Bucks blog.

headline: Workday Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: Workday, a provider of cloud-based applications for human resources, said on Monday that it would seek to price its initial public offering at $21 to $24 a share.

headline: You Should Try a Multi-Day Spending Cleanse
abstract: Going several days in a row without spending money may help you shake some bad financial habits – or recognize ones that you didn’t realize you had.

abstract: The video showing a subway encounter between a passenger and the rapper Jay-Z has brought my friend Ellen, an artist, much new attention. Of course, she also was called “an adorable old lady.”

headline: Election Commission Rule on Seizing Cash Roils Gujarat Businesses
abstract: Ahead of state elections, the election commission is confiscating undocumented cash in transit.

headline: Providence Equity’s Richardson to Assume Senior Adviser Role
abstract: Julie G. Richardson, a managing director at Providence Equity Partners and one of the most prominent female private equity executives, has reduced her responsibilities by becoming a senior adviser.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
abstract: AMC Networks’ flagship channel, AMC, came back to Dish on Sunday in time for the second episode of the new season of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: The Man Who Sparked Bollywood’s Love of Foreign Locales
abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

abstract: Coverage of Ravi Shankar in the New York Times spanned six decades.

headline: Review of Reviews: The Surface
abstract: Here is what other tech product reviewers thought of the Microsoft Surface.

headline: Oracle: Big Business Has Big Data Woes
abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: Olympics and Asset Sales Help Lift Comcast Profits
abstract: An increase in the average payment for a video subscription — to more than $150 month — helped the cable company offset a decline in the number of subscribers.

headline: Spending Time in School
abstract: Bucks readers talk about their experiences in helping a local school or alma mater.

headline: Monitoring Mandela and the Soul of a Nation
abstract: After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africa’s triumph over apartheid, was discharged from hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians raised fresh questions.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Fox News-MSNBC Campaign, and Sex Films’ Anti-H.I.V. Strategy
abstract: Also, an array of big-name performers campaigned with President Obama in the final days of the race, and AOL reported higher-than-expected revenue for the third quarter.

abstract: The top 50 start-ups, cold-calling strategies, cash flow concerns — and what would you do to revive Myspace?

abstract: The “Undo” command — popular in word-processing programs — also works to reverse accidental file moves on the computer’s desktop.

abstract: Dean Murphy, a deputy in the department, will become the new editor, replacing Larry Ingrassia, who will take on a larger role at the paper, according to a memo from the newspaper’s executive editor, Jill Abramson.

headline: ESPN Spurs Disney Gains, but Forecast Is Cautious

headline: Wall Street Stars Raise Their Lighters at Sandy Benefit Concert

abstract: A rise in Web sites and fiberglass idols divides Kolkata’s traditional idol-making community.

headline: Restoration Hardware Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: Restoration Hardware said in a filing on Tuesday that it planned to sell 5.2 million shares at $22 to $24 a share in an initial public offering.

headline: India Goes to the Races: A Weekend of Formula One
abstract: Great images from the race in Noida, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Possible Ripples From the Argentine Bond Litigation
abstract: Recent court decisions in the Argentine debt litigation seem to go a long way toward transforming the pari passu clause from a rule of rank into a prohibition on preferences.

headline: UBS to Cut 10,000 Jobs in Major Overhaul
abstract: The Swiss bank announced a wholesale restructuring of its investment banking division as it reported a third-quarter loss of $2.3 billion related to restructuring costs and charges connected to its own debt.

headline: The ‘Go Fast’ and ‘Go Big’ Fiscal Challenges

abstract: At a recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the topics included the upcoming election, health care, delegating, and assessing new employees.

headline: Ye Olde Partisanship Is Nothing New

headline: Big Bet Sours, Imperiling Small Firm
abstract: Rochdale, a small brokerage firm in Connecticut, is barely hanging on after one of its traders placed a billion-dollar bet on Apple stock that did not pay off.

abstract: Mitt Romney’s proposal to lower tax rates and close tax loopholes is unlikely to produce any meaningful economic growth, an economist writes.

abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Hard Times Could Create a Tech Boom
abstract: Cheer up. The bad news from Europe, the bad news from Dell and the modest forecasts for tech industry growth may also be a preamble to a tech-led economic revival.

headline: France Opens the Door to a Right to Die, but Not Now

headline: To Japan-China Row, Add One Potential Provocateur
abstract: The way ahead in the East China Sea — combat or compromise — could conceivably hang on one man, Shinzo Abe, who will be sworn in next week as prime minister of Japan. One Japan scholar said of Mr. Abe, “If he follows through on what he’s been saying, we could have serious problems.”

headline: A.I.G. Sells Remaining Stake in Asian Insurer for $6.5 Billion

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: CardNinja Cellphone Case
abstract: David Pogue gives on Day 3: CardNinja, a clever, stretchy-silky backpack for your cellphone. It holds cash and credit cards. Choice of colors, $18.

abstract: Microsoft threw a coming-out party for Windows 8 and the Surface tablet, its most significant new products in years. At an event in New York, the company’s chief executive, Steve Ballmer, showcased the tablet and new devices from its hardware partners that run Windows 8.

abstract: Apple reveals the iPad Mini. David Pogue reviews the Microsoft Surface in 60 seconds. The Mr. GIF artist collective.

abstract: Supreme Court allows visitors back in, with limits.

abstract: Despite impassioned pleas — and only after 24 hours of overtime — the already largely ineffective Kyoto Protocol was extended until 2020 when a more global emission reduction agreement, currently under negotiation, is to take effect.

abstract: The move is part of expansion plans from Vice, which says it is looking for companies that can benefit from its experience online.

abstract: Indian news outlets censored their reports, and Parliament was paralyzed.

abstract: There was more bad news for the euro zone in a bi-annual report Wednesday from the International Monetary Fund. Is Europe facing just another bump in the road, or are its chronic economic problems a sign of irreversible decline?

abstract: Most smart portable electronics have some kind of tracking software to locate lost or stolen gear – as long as the device’s battery is charged. A mobile security software suite called Lookout offers an app that shows where a device was when its battery died.

abstract: On fixing Mumbai’s transportation, housing and water problems, and the wrong-headed policies of his predecessors.

abstract: The D.J.’s, Mel Greig and Michael Christian of the Sydney station 2Day FM, had duped nurses at King Edward VII Hospital into revealing information about Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, who was being treated there for morning sickness.

abstract: As polarization deepens, desperately needed economic, political and judicial reforms stall. Television images of renewed clashes in Cairo, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez will bolster suspicions that the Muslim Brotherhood cannot be trusted.

abstract: Using Hurricane Sandy as a teaching tool, governors promote lower hurricane deductibles, how to drink like Hemingway and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: A new resource guide on the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act highlights the benefits to companies that voluntarily disclose potential violations and take remedial actions, but it leaves plenty of uncertainty.

abstract: Barclays has agreed to buy the British savings and loan business of the Dutch firm ING Group as Barclays shifts its focus toward retail banking.

abstract: The private equity giant will sell its investment in the gun maker after a rifle from the company’s Bushmaster brand was used by the gunman in the school shootings in Connecticut.

abstract: Facing accusations that it allowed American investors to bet on the outcome of wars and other world events without the blessing of regulators, Intrade announced on Monday that it was closing its Web site to United States residents.

abstract: Also, a video clip appears to show an American freelance journalist being held hostage in Syria, Tyler Perry signs on with Oprah Winfrey’s team, and a respected Hollywood script doctor goes behind the camera.

abstract: BP has reached a deal to sell its stake in TNK-BP to Rosneft. | Greg Smith’s book about Goldman Sachs goes on sale Monday. | Marissa Mayer holds her first earnings call as Yahoo’s chief executive. | A group led by Permira has agreed to buy Ancestry.com for $1.6 billion.

abstract: Jacques Brand has been appointed chief executive of Deutsche Bank’s North American operations.

abstract: His departure, scheduled for Feb. 1, comes as Sirius XM Radio prepares to be taken over by Liberty Media, its biggest investor.

abstract: Every month that business owners spend hunting for money instead of developing and marketing their product or service, they are wasting valuable time.

abstract: Consumer groups says a new federal court ruling could threaten the effectiveness of saferproducts.gov, a relatively new federal database of unsafe products.

abstract: The pop music scene in Northern Ireland seems as open as the landscape.

abstract: Egyptian voters approve Islamist-backed constitution; protests erupt over rape in New Delhi; Western boarding schools look to Asia; French museums turn to crowdfunding; a cricket legend takes a step back.

headline: Royalties for Satellite Radio Set to Rise Steadily Through 2017
abstract: The Copyright Royalty Board said the rate paid by Sirius XM Radio, the only satellite radio service in the United States, would increase each year from the current 8 percent of gross revenue to 11 percent in 2017.

headline: Navigating Medicare’s Open Enrollment Period
abstract: Medicare recipients can change options during open enrollment through Dec. 7.

abstract: The SodaStream home soda maker system, which bills itself as an alternative to bottled soft drinks, is joining the expensive ranks of advertisers during Super Bowl XLVII.

abstract: The owner of the New York Stock Exchange is in talks to be acquired by the IntercontinentalExchange, an upstart commodities and derivatives trading platform. | UBS made history on Wednesday when its Japanese unit agreed to plead guilty to fraud. | Shares of Herbalife began plummeting on Wednesday after reports that the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman was short-selling the company. | Some of John A. Paulson’s investors appear to be reconsidering whether they should keep their money with the hedge fund manager.

abstract: March stopped short of its New Delhi destination after a government agreement.

abstract: Jeremy Rifkin, the economist, author and the president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, is presenting the findings of a clean energy think tank in Barcelona. Watch video of his talk here from 2 p.m. central European time.

abstract: The company’s agreement with BrightLine is for a channel providing viewers content like video clips, offers and games.

headline: TimesCast: Engineering a Transit Miracle
abstract: Subways return more quickly than expected. | What becomes of the Treasury Department if Timothy F. Geithner leaves. | Zara finds success turning out cheap clothes with high-end style.

headline: Melee at the Opera: Catcalls for Paris ‘Médée’

abstract: A literary salon spreads from London to Paris and now to New York.

abstract: Some companies have already decided to pay out all or part of employees’ bonuses before Jan. 1, and many are considering following suit, compensation specialists report.

abstract: The IHT’s theater critic offers some suggestions for stage-hopping during the holidays.

abstract: Also, overseas publishers take on Google News, the continuing dispute over online music royalties, and BBC executives who missed opportunities to learn more about allegations of sexual abuse against Jimmy Savile.

headline: GrainCorp Rejects Revised Archer Daniels Bid
abstract: GrainCorp of Australia has rejected a $2.9 billion revised takeover offer from the Archer Daniels Midland Company, saying the bid undervalues the company.

abstract: The president and chief executive of Intel, Paul S. Otellini, is retiring in May after 40 years with the company. The company said it would prepare to transition to a new leader over the next six months.

headline: Daily Report: A Cold Shoulder for Amazon as Publisher

They are scorning the imprint’s most prominent title, Timothy Ferriss’s “The 4-Hour Chef.” That book is coming out just before Thanksgiving into a fragmented book-selling landscape.

headline: Choosing a Cover for Your Device
abstract: There are many choices for phone, tablet and laptop cases. The question is, do you want style or protection?

headline: Lundberg Farms Responds to Reader Comments
abstract: The only way forward, Tim Schultz, a third-generation Lundberg said, is to continue sharing information and conducting research into mitigation strategies.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels

abstract: Also, the German offshoot of The Financial Times decides to stop publishing, and Quebec orders big United States retailers to translate their names into French.

headline: Politicians and Their Personal Finances
abstract: Readers weigh in on what, if any, personal financial failings should be disqualifying for politicians who ask for our vote.

headline: Secrecy and Power in China
abstract: Can China become truly modern and powerful by operating old systems of power that rely on so much secrecy and ignorance?

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 5
