headline: Graphic: A Long Line of Accounting Scandals
abstract: Hewlett-Packard said that it had taken an $8.8 billion accounting charge, after discovering “serious accounting improprieties” and “outright misrepresentations” at Autonomy, a British software maker that it bought for $10 billion last year. The computer company is the latest in a string of companies linked to cases of accounting problems.

headline: One on One: Jim Wicks, Design Chief at Motorola Mobility
abstract: Motorola Mobility, which was acquired by Google in May, recently released new smartphones and reintroduced itself as the “New Motorola.” But what does that mean? In an interview, Jim Wicks, Motorola’s design chief, talked about the company’s design strategy and how it will change.

headline: Visualizing the Impact of C.D. Laddering
abstract: Ally Bank starts a tool to help visualize the benefits of laddering certificates of deposit, a process that can yield hundreds more dollars in savings even when interest rates are low.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 17
abstract: A performance of the martial art form, Kalaripayattu, at a fair in Punjab.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Health Care Hackers and Guns for Christmas
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include people showing off their Christmas guns on Instagram, Electronic Arts receiving more than $9 million in tax credits from Florida and Zynga retiring 11 of its games.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Nov. 29
abstract: News and arts from today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Knight Capital and Getco to Merge
abstract: The $1.4 billion deal will give Getco, the privately held high-speed trading firm, a public listing in a new holding company.

headline: Duff & Phelps to Be Sold for $665.5 Million
abstract: Duff & Phelps said on Sunday that it had reached a $665.5 million deal to be acquired by a consortium including the Carlyle Group, Stone Point Capital and the Edmond de Rothschild Group.

headline: Group Finds More Gay and Lesbian Characters on Television
abstract: GLAAD, a group that advocates for diversity in the media, reviewed the scripted shows for this season, and determined that there are more gay and lesbian characters on television than ever before.

headline: Fixing a Credit Card Mix-Up for Stay-at-Home Spouses
abstract: A fix is on the way for a restriction that forced card companies to consider individual income and not household income.

headline: Ackman Steps Up Pressure on General Growth
abstract: William Ackman, the hedge fund manager, reiterated on Monday his position that General Growth Properties, a Chicago-based mall operator, should consider selling itself to the Simon Property Group.

headline: Apple Fires a Manager Over Its Misfire on Maps
abstract: Apple continues to clean house after it stumbled badly with its mobile mapping service, firing a manager who oversaw it. Eddy Cue, the senior vice president for Internet software and services at Apple, fired the manager, Richard Williamson, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Four Old Spice Ads Make YouTube’s List of Most Popular Ads of 2012
abstract: The list records an often overlooked fact: Americans sometimes choose to watch commercials. Trailing Old Spice, which had the most on the Top 20, were Nike and Volkswagen.

headline: A Rare Quiet Zone During the Presidential Election: Spanish-Language Media
abstract: In 10 key states, the presidential campaigns spent $22.8 million on local Spanish-language media outlets, or just 6.2 percent of the total spent on advertising in those states.

headline: Rights Group Says Its Researcher in Moscow Is Threatened
abstract: Human Rights Watch says that a staff member received repeated threats this week of an attack focused on her pregnancy.

headline: Fraud Trial Begins in Multimillion-Dollar Afghan Bank Scandal

headline: Early Dividend for Wal-Mart Is Latest Move in Tax Tactics
abstract: Rescheduling dividend payments and selling stocks are among the strategies being employed to avoid higher tax rates set to take effect in 2013.

headline: In This Sell-Off, No One Pressed the Panic Button
abstract: Yes, the stock market took a tumble after the election. But a strategist says the selling has looked “extraordinarily rational and level-headed.”

headline: Egypt’s Chief Prosecutor Resists President’s Effort to Oust Him
abstract: President Mohamed Morsi tried to name the prosecutor, a holdover from the Mubarak era, ambassador to the Vatican.

headline: Slower Growth Seen in a Graying World
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development forecasts that global growth in gross domestic product will fall as the proportion of older people rises.

headline: Former Judge Opens Inquiry Into Savile Sexual Abuse Case
abstract: A former judge is examining the “culture and practices” that lay behind the sexual abuse furor swirling around the television host Jimmy Savile and the BBC.

abstract: In China, officials at state-run schools demand steep payoffs from parents who want their children to get an academic edge.

abstract: After a former executive, Greg Smith, resigned from Goldman Sachs in a letter to The New York Times, he fails to deliver much more in his book on the firm.

abstract: A demonstration against American drone strikes inside Pakistan’s tribal belt was abandoned after the military warned of “imminent danger,” but thousands rallied at a safer location.

abstract: The French government’s plan to increase the beer tax by 160 percent has upset brewers, beer drinkers and bar owners, who ask why the proposal does not affect winemakers.

abstract: An Islamist-backed constitution was approved by voters, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over Egypt’s future.

headline: U.S. Will Place Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
abstract: The Commerce Department issued its final ruling Wednesday in a long-simmering trade dispute with China, imposing tariffs ranging from about 34 to 47 percent on most solar panels imported from the country.

headline: Europe Reaches Agreement on System for Patents
abstract: The bickering that has plagued the development of a uniform patent system in Europe foreshadows the problems that another crucial effort, the creation of a banking union, could face.

headline: Mutual Fund Leaders Aim to End Jam Over Rules

abstract: European data protection officials are drafting plans to censure Google over its online privacy policy if the company does not eventually meet regulators' demands to revise it.

abstract: Officials said that those arrested planned to use car bombs, machine guns and other heavy weapons at diplomatic targets and shopping malls.

abstract: A weekend standstill involving 10,000 vehicles between Moscow and St. Petersburg refocused attention on the state of Soviet-era infrastructure.

abstract: The drug maker Mylan is suing the Food and Drug Administration in an attempt to upend its rival Ranbaxy’s exclusive rights to produce a generic form of Diovan, a blood pressure drug.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

abstract: The Rev. Alvaro Corcuera, superior general of the Legionaries of Christ, a worldwide religious order besieged by a sex scandal, stepped aside on Thursday, citing poor health.

abstract: To promote its new mascara, Lancôme has licensed the cartoon character Betty Boop and is pairing her in print and video ads with the model Daria Werbowy.

abstract: As a newly formed opposition coalition started talks on Wednesday, there were reports that insurgents had shot down another government aircraft.

abstract: Several new Super Bowl advertisers are teasing the contents in advance and providing entire commercials before the game.

abstract: In its second major effort to revive a flagging economy, the Indian cabinet proposed letting foreign investors take a bigger stake in insurance and pension companies, but passage of the measure by Parliament is far from certain.

abstract: The writer looks at the issues of 2012 that stirred reader passions, and found that she got the most responses to one column on robocalls and another on redefining success.

abstract: The fighters said they had taken control of Harem, a strategic town on the Turkish border, as the international envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, remained in Damascus.

headline: Europe Foresees Weak Recovery Next Year
abstract: Unemployment will remain at “very high” levels, according to a gloomy set of forecasts issued by the European Commission.

abstract: At least 111 bodies were recovered from a garment factory fire, and scores of injured were taken to hospitals with burns and smoke inhalation injuries.

abstract: Critics of Medicare appear to be speaking cryptically to avoid spelling out how they want to change popular provisions of the national health insurance program, an economist writes.

abstract: Starbucks opens its first outlet in India, in Mumbai, but offers few details about its plans for the country.

headline: Rendezvous’s Editor on Where the Conflicts Could Erupt in U.S. Vote
abstract: Marcus Mabry sits down with the political editor of The New York Times, Richard Stevenson, to discuss the pressure points to watch tonight.

headline: At the Heart of a Political Brawl in India, Two Historic Newspapers
abstract: Plans to revive papers started by Jawaharlal Nehru in 1938 are targeted by a sharp critic of the Gandhi family.

headline: Clearwire Is Sought by Sprint for Spectrum
abstract: Sprint disclosed on Thursday that it had offered to buy a stake in Clearwire from its founder, Craig O. McCaw, the cellphone pioneer, effectively giving it majority control of the struggling broadband company.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reports $1 Billion Loss but Beats Forecasts
abstract: Morgan Stanley earnings rebounded strongly in the third quarter as skittish clients returned to doing business with the company. A ratings downgrade in June was not as far as some had feared, and resulted in a bump in business.

headline: Graphene Could Usher in Flexible, Ultra-Slim Gadgets
abstract: Graphene, which is considered a “wonder material,” could allow manufacturers to make cell phones as thin as a piece of paper and fully flexible.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Crime Maps and Internet Radio Trouble
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes the sentencing of three men in the Hewlett-Packard spying case who worked for a private investigation firm, a look at the economics of online music services and an argument that paying money for software can be more enjoyable than paying for it via advertising and a loss of privacy.

headline: Debating the Death Sentence for ‘Honor’ Killings
abstract: Five family members were sentenced to death for the killing of a couple who married against their wishes.

headline: A Pay Cut for Tim Cook? Not Really
abstract: Apple filed documents with regulators revealing that its chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, took what might look like a significant pay cut in 2012. But the giant stock package Mr. Cook received last year will vest over 10 years.

headline: Credit Suisse Said to Cut Investment Bank Jobs in Britain
abstract: Credit Suisse is eliminating 100 jobs at its investment banking operation in Britain as part of its cost-cutting program, according to a person with direct knowledge of the plan.

headline: Poisoned Agent’s Wife Faces Financial Duress
abstract: Just as Marina Litvinenko’s long campaign to secure a hearing for her dead husband seems to be nearing a climax, her funding has dried up.

headline: S.E.C.’s Fair but Futile Stance on China-Based Auditors
abstract: China’s shaky accounting practices are a sound target for U.S. regulators. Or at least, they would have been 10 years ago, contends John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Another Day, Another Set of Insider Trading Cases
abstract: Prosecutors say an insurance executive in Denver traded on secret information about Kirk Kerkorian’s firm acquiring a significant stake in an oil and gas company. Also Friday, a former employee of the former hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam agreed to pay $1.75 million to settle a civil lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Getting That Extra Mile Out of Plastic
abstract: We can try to use less plastic, or even live without it, but turning waste plastic into fuel is an idea that makes sense, since most plastics are petroleum-based.

headline: Dead Phone Battery? Just Burn Something.
abstract: After Hurricane Sandy knocked out power in the Northeast, a New York start-up came up with a good publicity stunt: light a fire so people could charge their dead cellphones.

headline: Penguin to Publish 2012 Campaign Book From Authors of ‘Game Change’
abstract: “Double Down: Game Change 2012,” by Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, is set for fall 2013 publication. HBO has optioned the rights, as it did with the authors’ earlier work on the 2008 presidential race, which was turned into a movie.

headline: Increasing Savings With Promotional C.D. Rates
abstract: Bonus or promotional rates on certificates of deposit can offer higher interest rates.

headline: Walk in a Mall, Receive a Mobile Coupon
abstract: RetailMeNot, a Web site for e-commerce coupons, now offers coupons for stores at the mall that appear on your phone when you are nearby.

headline: Q&A: Removing a Firefox Add-on
abstract: If you suspect that nifty browser add-on is slowing Firefox down, you can disable or remove it.

headline: Image of the Day: Oct. 9
abstract: The birth anniversary of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh “Guru” or spiritual leader, celebrated in Amritsar, Punjab.

headline: Friday Reading: How Extended Doctor Office Hours Save Money
abstract: How extended medical office hours save money, getting more out of your smart phone, time to make the Halloween costumes (or not) and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: China Calls for ‘No Delay’ on Gun Controls in U.S.
abstract: China, which enforces a near-total ban on the private possession of firearms, has called for stricter gun controls in the United States. On the same day that a gunman killed 20 first-graders and six women at a school in Connecticut, a man in China stabbed 22 children and an 85-year-old woman. There were no fatalities in that attack, although some of the children reportedly had their ears and fingers cut off.

headline: Facebook Offers to Sweeten Deal to Settle ‘Sponsored Stories’ Suit
abstract: In an effort to settle a pending class action suit, Facebook offers $10 to every user whose name and picture was used in a Sponsored Stories ad.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 20
abstract: The two-day India-ASEAN summit began in New Delhi on Thursday.

headline: Do You Have Corruption Fatigue?
abstract: Telltale signs include inappropriate humor, or despair.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Approves a Google Maps App
abstract: The return of a Google-powered maps application to the iPhone may make it easier for Apple’s customers to find their way. But it will not relieve Apple of the pressure to bring its own maps service up to snuff, Nick Wingfield reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Image of the Day: Nov. 22
abstract: The winter session of Parliament began on Thursday.

headline: Bain Capital Thanks Investors for Support During Presidential Campaign
abstract: Few private enterprises faced as much scrutiny during the presidential campaign than Bain Capital, given its ties to Mitt Romney. With election season over, the private equity firm is giving thanks to investors for putting up with that harsh glare.

headline: The Recovery Spreads
abstract: The job gains, previously concentrated among the oldest workers, are now predominantly among those in the prime working years.

headline: Why Sinofsky Left: A Web Roundup
abstract: The announcement of Steven Sinofsky’s ouster from Microsoft came late on Monday, so the story has only begun to be reported. Here is what various news organizations and bloggers are saying.

headline: Image of the Day: Nov. 26
abstract: Activist-turned-politician Arvind Kejriwal, launched his political party, on Monday.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
abstract: AMC Networks’ flagship channel, AMC, came back to Dish on Sunday in time for the second episode of the new season of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: The Man Who Sparked Bollywood’s Love of Foreign Locales
abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

headline: Outside India, Shankar Fascinated Generations of Fans
abstract: Coverage of Ravi Shankar in the New York Times spanned six decades.

headline: Review of Reviews: The Surface
abstract: Here is what other tech product reviewers thought of the Microsoft Surface.

headline: Oracle: Big Business Has Big Data Woes
abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: Nokia to Offer Its Maps for iPhones and Android Phones
abstract: Nokia still hasn’t found its way to a successful comeback in the smartphone market, but the company is preparing to share its mapping data with its competitors Apple and Google.

headline: I.B.M. Chief on Watson, Cognitive Computing and Her Tenure
abstract: Virginia M. Rometty, chief executive and chairman of I.B.M., says the company’s new mission, teaching machines to learn, is the third wave of computing and will transform jobs in every industry. Her advice to fellow CEOs: “Never love something so much that you can’t let go of it.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Protecting Medical Records and Santa’s Naughty List
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes hacker attacks in the health care sector, a 3D Christmas message from the queen of England, and Santa’s privacy policy.

headline: Daily Report: First Step in Overhaul of E-Mail Privacy Law
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill on Thursday that would strengthen privacy protection for e-mails, Charlie Savage reports on Friday in The New York Times. The bill would require law enforcement officials to obtain a warrant from a judge in most cases before gaining access to messages stored in individual accounts.

headline: Christian Aid Worker Is Shot in Pakistan
abstract: In an upscale suburb of Lahore on Monday, a Christian charity worker from Sweden was shot outside her home. On the same day, in the same neighborhood, more than a hundred headstones in the graveyard of a minority Muslim sect were vandalized by masked gunmen.

headline: Europe Reaches Budget Deal on Space
abstract: Europe’s contentious budget talks collapsed as national leaders fought in Brussels. But, in a more modest forum in Naples, ministers reached a deal to ensure the Continent’s future in space development.

headline: Letter From the American West: Gun Debate Misses the Mark
abstract: I live in two countries, have worked in just about all the rest and have had weapons drawn on me by child soldiers, terrorists and bandits. In none of those circumstances would being armed have increased my chances of being here today.

headline: Bank C.E.O.’s on Thinning Ice
abstract: At least one of the three big bank chief executives to survive the financial crisis could be without a job by the end of 2013, the authors contend.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Renting Your Own Private Ski Resort
abstract: Renting your own private ski resort, when your date wants to know your credit score, selling your own iBooks and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 24
abstract: Fans gear up for the India-Pakistan cricket match scheduled for Christmas day in Bangalore, Karnataka.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Fix-It Job in Fixed Income
abstract: Colm Kelleher, who was named the sole head of Morgan Stanley’s securities arm on Monday, faces some significant challenges in transforming the bank’s fixed-income division.

headline: Questions Remain Over Hewlett’s Big Charge on Autonomy Acquisition
abstract: In its annual report, Hewlett-Packard discusses the methodology it employed when making the $8.8 billion charge, but it does not break out exactly how purported accounting improprieties were behind $5 billion of that charge.

headline: Goldman Beats Expectations
abstract: Goldman Sachs swung to a profit in the third quarter. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says lawsuits brought by the government “may have a profound impact” on how businesses view the next crisis. | SoftBank is betting it can break the dominance of Verizon and AT&T.

headline: Congress Poised to Wrestle Himachal Pradesh From B.J.P.
abstract: Ouster of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party is expected in today’s election.

headline: What They Said: Indian Politicians on Ajmal Kasab’s Execution
abstract: Indian politicians and lawmakers on the hanging of the Pakistani gunman behind the Mumbai 2008 attacks.

headline: The People Who Make Up Citi’s Board
abstract: A check of Citigroup’s board roster, which reportedly clashed with Vikram S. Pandit, reveals a number of former Wall Street executives with lengthy experience in banking. Many of the directors joined the board only in the last four years.

headline: 2nd Debate Also a Ratings Hit, Drawing 65.6 Million At-Home Viewers
abstract: The big cable winner was Fox News, with the biggest audience in the channel’s history.

headline: Google Shopping Becomes More Amazon-Like
abstract: In the latest example of the competition for shopping search between Google and Amazon.com, Google Shopping has introduced tools like wish lists and reviews that are similar to tools on Amazon.

headline: Murdoch Stirs Criticism With a Twitter Post
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of News Corporation, apologized for a remark about the Israel-Gaza conflict that many people called anti-Semitic.

headline: From Bubble to Muddling Through?
abstract: Last week’s column examined the confusing picture for China’s growth. New data is out, and the outlook is still confusing.

headline: Among Top News Stories, a War Is Missing
abstract: The war in Afghanistan and worldwide counterterrorism efforts were absent from polls that ranked 2012’s top stories, reflecting the scant coverage of the issues as well as the public’s lack of interest.

headline: ‘Gangnam Style’ Becomes Most-Watched Video Ever on YouTube — 805 Million Views
abstract: “Gangnam Style,” the surprise hit by the South Korean rapper Psy, has replaced Justin Bieber’s “Baby” as the most-watched video of all time on YouTube.

headline: The Obama Campaign’s Technology Is a Force Multiplier
abstract: Leaders of the technology team in the Obama campaign explain that the big payoff from powerful new computing tools was to strengthen its decisive ground game.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Planning a Vegetarian Thanksgiving
abstract: Planning a vegetarian Thanksgiving, a 401(k) that promises never to run dry, Key West gets more nonstop flights and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Image of the Day: Oct. 29
abstract: Sharad Purnima celebrated in New Delhi.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bloomberg and The Financial Times, and the First ‘Telecopter’
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg has been cagey about whether he might acquire The Financial Times; he is reported to have said, “I buy it every day.” Also, John McAfee on the run, reporters in tow; and John Silva, the engineer at a Los Angeles TV station who fashioned the first TV helicopter, dies at 92.

headline: Huntsman, Former U.S. Ambassador, Says China Blocked His Speech
abstract: Jon Huntsman Jr., the former U.S. envoy to China and ex-presidential candidate, says Beijing kept him from delivering a speech last month for political reasons.

headline: A Bigger Paycheck on Wall Street
abstract: The New York State Comptroller says in a report that total compensation on Wall Street rose 4 percent last year to more than $60 billion — an amount surpassed only by total pay in 2007 and 2008.

headline: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh Appeals for ‘Peace and Calm’
abstract: Mr. Singh addressed the nation on Monday.

headline: Vice-Presidential Debate Draws More Than 50 Million Viewers
abstract: The number was considerably down from the Biden-Palin debate in 2008 but larger than any other since 1984.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 28
abstract: Harsh Islamist justice in Mali; Putin says American adoptions will end; more meetings as the fiscal cliff looms; better conditions in Chinese plants; a silver lining for Spain.

headline: Bank of England’s New Leader, a Member of the ‘Government Sachs’ Club
abstract: The announcement that Mark Carney will serve as the next head of the Bank of England shows that the “Government Sachs” meme isn’t going anywhere.

headline: A Closer Look at Romney’s Small-Business Tax and Jobs Claims
abstract: The numbers Governor Romney used in the first presidential debate are startling. But are they accurate?

headline: A Trip Down the Short, Sad Path of Old Lane
abstract: The purchase of the Old Lane hedge fund cost Citigroup $800 million and netted Vikram Pandit $165 million. At the time, the purchase was more about buying Mr. Pandit, a former Morgan Stanley star, than it was about adding the roughly $4.5 billion in assets his firm held to Citi’s fold.

headline: When the Tax Tail Wags Your Investment Dog
abstract: A myopic focus on the tax implications of an investment may keep people from seeing the bigger picture of their finances.

headline: Bain Capital to Buy Call Center Business for $1.3 Billion
abstract: The private equity firm co-founded by the U.S. presidential candidate Mitt Romney has agreed to buy the call center unit of the European telecoms giant Telefónica for $1.3 billion.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Antarctican Visions and Hipstamatic’s Struggle
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes Ira Glass answering questions, a tale of the S.E.C. pushing Facebook to reveal risks before its stock offering and more online retailers opening offline stores.

headline: Violence and Pepper Spray During Nasheed’s Arrest in Maldives, Party Claims
abstract: Police dispute his account, say they even stopped for cigarettes on the way to jail.

headline: Of Parents, Puppies and Robots
abstract: Methods of assessing the cost and benefits of children often fail to acknowledge the broader benefits that they bring society, particularly in caring for older generations, an economist writes.

headline: Reckitt Benckiser Makes Rival Bid for Schiff Nutrition
abstract: The Reckitt Benckiser Group is offering $42 a share in cash for Schiff Nutrition International, topping a deal for $34 a share, or $1.2 billion, between Schiff and the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer that was announced on Oct. 30.

abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Privacy’s Price Tag, and Pandora Money
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes an app that estimates how much money Google and Facebook make from you each year and a report that iPhone users in Finland are sending fewer text messages.

headline: Apple and the Desire for Control
abstract: Apple is the first, last and only word on which apps are allowed on its array of mobile devices. It is a system that has worked out very well for Apple, its customers and some developers. At what point does it become something to worry about?

headline: On Twitter, Steve Jobs Is Immortal
abstract: Steve Jobs is represented in a lot of parodies, rants, marketing hooks and memorials in the form of Twitter accounts under variations of his name. Compared with the treatment of President Obama, they are pretty respectful. Compared with Justin Bieber, they are legion.

headline: Bulls and Bears Fight It Out, in Courts
abstract: Intrigue continues to circle around Silvercorp Metals, a Chinese mining company incorporated in Canada and traded in New York, with new investigations about its financial dealings reported.

headline: Time Warner Cable to Charge Modem Rental Fee
abstract: Time Warner Cable, the big broadband and cable provider, is planning to start charging customers a monthly fee of $3.95 for renting a cable modem. It said in notifications mailed to customers this week that the new fee would go into effect over the next two months.

headline: Twitter Says It Was Not Hacked
abstract: Many Twitter users received e-mails on Thursday asking them to reset the passwords to their Twitter accounts, spurring concerns that their Twitter account, or that Twitter itself, may have been breached. Not so.

headline: Breath-Stopping Surprises, Texas-Sized Triumph at the U.S. Grand Prix
abstract: The inaugural United States Grand Prix in Austin, Texas was a resounding success in just about every way — but especially in the track and the racing itself.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Live as Long as an Olympian
abstract: How to live as long as an Olympian, what the Delta-Virgin deal means for fliers, anger over Instagram changes and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: A Budget for Regulation
abstract: It’s hard to assess the cost of government regulations unless the public is provided a clear accounting of what is spent and what the return is on that investment, an economist writes.

headline: From Its Charity Efforts, Aflac Learns What Works in Social Media
abstract: The insurance company, which works with Macy’s to sell toy versions of its duck mascot in support of pediatric cancer hospitals, is enlisting a range of social-networking sites.

headline: With Game Awards Ceremony, Xbox Users to Direct the Show
abstract: Microsoft and Spike TV are making a push to make television interactive with the Video Game Awards, an annual ceremony that Xbox users will be able to shape themselves during its live broadcast. Xbox viewers will be able to respond to live polls and decide which spoof videos will be shown.

headline: In Boost to U.S. Plans, BBC World News Is Added to Time Warner Cable
abstract: The channel has been aggressively seeking American distribution, and the Time Warner Cable arrangements add 10 million homes.

headline: Visit by Letterman, a Hero and a Rival, Lifts Kimmel’s Ratings
abstract: The appearance with Mr. Kimmel, who is broadcasting this week from Brooklyn, drew the show’s highest ratings for a Wednesday night.

headline: UBS Revamps Its Investment Bank
abstract: Only days after the Swiss bank UBS announced 10,000 job cuts as part of a major overhaul, the bank has begun to reorganize its investment banking unit, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Q&A: Erasing Your Video-Viewing History
abstract: Google’s YouTube site and Chrome browser keep history lists of the videos you have viewed with your YouTube account, but you can erase them.

headline: Q&A: Deleting the Conversation in Word
abstract: When that Microsoft Word document is finally complete and everyone who worked on it is happy, you can remove all the comments embedded in the file at once.

headline: Korean-American Star Confesses in Skating Scandal
abstract: Simon Cho, an Olympic medalist and a reigning world champion, has confessed to bending a blade on the skate of a Canadian short-track competitor. The Korean-American star, who turned 21 on Sunday, said he was badgered into the sabotage by the South Korean coach who has led the U.S. national team since 2007.

headline: Deutsche Bank Says Earnings Will Be Weak
abstract: A day after prosecutors raided its headquarters in a tax-evasion investigation, Deutsche Bank disclosed that earnings would be weak, but called it “guidance” rather than a “profit warning.”

headline: Perella Weinberg Hires Gatto, a Veteran Mergers Adviser
abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners has hired Joseph D. Gatto as a partner and senior banker focused on the consumer and industrial sectors. A veteran deal maker, Mr. Gatto most recently worked at Barclays.

headline: Further Thoughts on the Brilliant Jerk
abstract: If you want to remain a small company, spend your time managing and pacifying the Brilliant Jerk.

headline: Archer Daniels Raises Bid for GrainCorp
abstract: The Archer Daniels Midland Company raised its offer for GrainCorp of Australia on Monday, valuing the grain processor at about $2.9 billion, as A.D.M. pressed ahead with its unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: A Shanghai That Didn’t Last
abstract: For several years, a correspondent-turned-photographer documented the buildings, the neighborhoods and the way of life that disappeared to make way for a landscape of high-rise buildings that is the new Shanghai. There was no room for these communities in the image that the city envisioned for itself.

headline: Ex-Goldman Director to Serve 2 Years in Insider Case
abstract: Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director, was sentenced to two years in prison on Wednesday for leaking boardroom secrets to the former hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Real Books, and Windows Confusion
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes a comic that looks at artificial intelligence, a celebration of books that aren’t electronic and the mystery (for many people) of Windows RT.

headline: Thursday Reading: Avoiding Too Much Stuff at the Holidays
abstract: Avoiding too much stuff at the holidays, car insurance by the mile, the benefits of running in reverse and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Household Income Stagnates, Again
abstract: Inflation-adjusted median annual household income was more or less flat in October, at $51,378.

headline: Choosing Sides on Regulating the Press
abstract: In the drama following the Leveson inquiry’s controversial recommendations on how to discipline an unruly British press, many political actors are playing against type.

headline: Airbnb Responds to Questions About Hosts Breaking Local Laws
abstract: Why doesn’t Airbnb give users more information about local zoning laws? And does it want hosts to take down all listings where they are violating the law?

headline: Tuesday Reading: Youth Obesity Falls in Several Cities
abstract: Obesity in the young falls in several cities, trains fill gaps in airline schedules, borrowing e-books from the library and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: New Push for Money Fund Rules
abstract: The S.E.C. is being pressed to adopt new rules for money market funds. | Lawyers for two former hedge fund managers in an insider trading case are trying to discredit government witnesses. | About 804 million Facebook shares are becoming eligible to be sold. | Costco, Walmart and Home Depot are giving new meaning to the term “retail bank.”

headline: Tiger Global Takes 9.9% Stake in Groupon
abstract: The $8 billion hedge fund has taken a 9.9 percent stake in Groupon, as the daily deals company’s stock hovers near all-time lows.

headline: Despite Fiscal Shadow, Consumer Confidence Rises
abstract: The more buoyant feeling, particularly strong among those over 55, is focused on expectations for the economy, rather than current conditions.

headline: Senator Demands F.A.A. Relax Electronics Rules
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri sent a letter to the Federal Aviation Administration urging the agency to allow the use of electronics during the full duration of a flight. She threatened to push for legislation if the agency took too long.

headline: Nomura Faces Another Insider Trading Case
abstract: On Friday, the Japanese bank said it was likely involved in a new insider trading case, months after the firm’s chief executive, Kenichi Watanabe, resigned following similar allegations.

headline: Facebook Changes Privacy Settings, Again
abstract: Facebook introduced a number of new privacy settings on Wednesday, some of which will be met with approval and others that may upset privacy advocates.

headline: Anonymous Attacks Israeli Web Sites
abstract: After Israel killed a top military commander of Hamas, the hacker group Anonymous retaliated with attacks on several Israeli Web sites, taking down one military blogging site and defacing the site of an Israeli surveillance company..

headline: A Conversation With: Devendrakumar R. Desai, Gandhian, Champion of Khadi
abstract: Khadi, the fabric popularized by M. K. Gandhi, is finding new buyers in India and being aggressively promoted abroad.

headline: What Man Santa: Holiday Cheer From Mumbai’s Bandra
abstract: Bollywood musician Daniel B. George’s quirky Christmas tune “What Man Santa” goes viral.

headline: ‘Garlands and Mud’ for New Nobel Laureate from China
abstract: The novelist Mo Yan was due to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature on Monday, a selection acidly assailed by fellow writers and poets in China. And while some applauded the award, Herta Müller, the 2009 Nobel laureate, called Mr. Mo’s selection “a catastrophe” because of his failure to condemn state censorship in China.

abstract: Bucks readers offer their advice on steps to take to protect your personal assets.

abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: Arthur C. Clarke E-Books for Sale in U.S.
abstract: Thirty-five titles by the author of “2001: A Space Odyssey” are now available for $8.99 each.

headline: Sprint Clinches Deal With SoftBank
abstract: Sprint Nextel is selling a 70 percent stake to SoftBank of Japan. | Bank earnings continue with Citigroup. | Two Americans are awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. | The A.C.L.U. is taking aim at Morgan Stanley’s mortgage machine.

headline: I.B.M. Reports Nanotube Chip Breakthrough
abstract: I.B.M. scientists say they have found a way to help chip makers keep shrinking the size of the microchips that power today’s digital devices.

headline: Plush Pets That Parrot Your Speaking
abstract: Toys have inspired apps, so it was only a matter of time before an app inspired a physical toy. Two of the popular Talking Friends apps – Talking Tom Cat and Talking Ben the Dog – are now plush toys, which, of course, talk.

headline: Barnes & Noble Continues Push in Britain
abstract: The bookseller is introducing an advertising campaign in Britain meant to pull in customers there for the holiday season. It is emphasizing its new e-ink products, like the Nook Simple Touch.

headline: Icahn Bids to Take Control of Oshkosh Truck
abstract: Carl C. Icahn escalated his proxy fight with the vehicle maker Oshkosh Corporation on Thursday by offering to take over the company for $32.50 a share, or about $3 billion.

headline: UBS Is Reported to Be Near a Deal on Rate Rigging
abstract: The Swiss banking giant UBS is expected to pay American and British fines of more than $450 million to settle claims that it reported false rates to increase its profit, according to officials briefed on the matter.

headline: Merkel Reaches Out to Greece With German Voters in Mind
abstract: Why is Angela Merkel being nice to the Greeks? As the German Chancellor arrived in Athens on Tuesday for a one-day visit, commentators suggested the answer might lie in domestic German politics.

headline: A Conversation With: Conservative Author and Filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza
abstract: Most Indian-Americans are actually to the right of presidential candidate Mitt Romney, D’Souza argues.

headline: Daily Report: Mobile Devices Change Doctors’ Rounds
abstract: The proliferation of gadgets, apps and Web-based information has given the medical profession a black bag of new tools, Katie Hafner reports in Tuesday’s New York Times. Clinicians have new ways to diagnose symptoms and treat patients, to obtain and share information, to think about what it means to be both a doctor and a patient.

headline: Should You Have to Pay Taxes on Forgiven Student Loan Debt?
abstract: Bucks readers weigh in on whether forgiven student loan debt should come with a fat tax bill from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Is Barcelona About to Get a New Museum?
abstract: Baroness Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza helped transform Madrid’s arts scene 20 years ago. Is she about to do the same for Barcelona? And will there be strings attached?

headline: British Authorities Charge Hedge Fund Founder
abstract: The founder of Weavering Capital, one of Britain’s oldest hedge funds, has been charged with fraud, fraudulent trading and false accounting.

headline: For Elmo, Perseverance in the Macy’s Parade
abstract: The beloved “Sesame Street” character, who has been in the news this month because of accusations made against the puppeteer who plays him, appeared alongside Big Bird as the show’s float made its way into Herald Square.

headline: Morgan Stanley Makes Donation After Sandy Hook Massacre
abstract: Morgan Stanley, where three employees lost family members in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, has donated $150,000 to charities honoring the victims. In addition, about 1,400 employees have made pledges, contributing just over $1 million in total.

headline: Restructurings and the Impact of Credit-Default Swaps
abstract: A disclosure requirement might be one way to address the “empty creditor” problem that comes up in times of financial distress.

headline: India’s Foreign Minister Resigns
abstract: S.M. Krishna, 80, is not expected to return to politics in his home state.

headline: A Money Saving Phone Service Is Revived
abstract: Validas, a site that analyzed consumer phone bills then suggested lower-priced plans, had shut down but is back as Vera.

headline: Inquiries to Watch in a Second Term
abstract: There are not likely to be any new, sweeping investigations involving white-collar crime in President Obama’s second term, but prominent cases involving the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the fallout from the 2008 financial crisis loom.

headline: A Lie That’s Good for Password Security
abstract: Answering security questions with an unrelated answer can make for easy-to-remember and hard-to-break passwords.

headline: Louis Dreyfus and JPMorgan to Sell Energy Trading Venture
abstract: A joint venture of Louis Dreyfus and a hedge fund owned by JPMorgan Chase has announced plans to sell an energy trading business to a group of investors, including Paul Tudor Jones.

headline: Google Cranks Up Its Patent Engine
abstract: Google has been sharply increasing its generation of patents, and they are high-quality patents filed around the world, according to a new report from Thomson Reuters. The fierce competition and rapid innovation in the smartphone industry are feeding the patent surge at Google.

headline: Image of the Day: Nov. 9
abstract: Clear weather prevails in New Delhi after days of smog.

headline: When the Transition Out of the Service Is Less Than Smooth
abstract: The Army refers to separation from service as a “transition,” implying something akin to moving steadily along a continuum. In reality, the experience is abrupt.

headline: Week in Review: Portraits of a Hedge Fund Titan
abstract: The inquiry into Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund intensified. | The race to run the S.E.C. shifted. | Andrew Ross Sorkin examined the peril of “expert networks.” | A news analysis finds a housing tax break is vulnerable. | And Lehman sold a property firm that helped sink it.

headline: Penguin to Expand E-Book Lending
abstract: Working with Baker & Taylor, a distributor of print and digital books, Penguin will start the new pilot programs this year.

headline: An Election Probably Shouldn’t Change Your Financial Plan
abstract: Just because we know the identity of our president for the next four years and have uncertainty about the approaching budget showdown doesn’t mean we should make a bunch of quick money moves.

headline: JPMorgan Beats Expectations
abstract: JPMorgan Chase kicked off bank earnings season, announcing a 34 percent rise in profit. | Paul E. Singer, the head of Elliott Management, “may have met his match.” | When Timothy F. Geithner wants insight into Wall Street, he often turns to the head of BlackRock. | Workday is set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: 2 Former Hedge Fund Managers Found Guilty in Insider Trading Case
abstract: Anthony Chiasson, a co-founder of Level Global Investors, and Todd Newman, a former portfolio manager at Diamondback Capital Management, were found guilty on charges that they participated in a conspiracy that made more than $70 million illegally trading technology stocks.

headline: Q&A: Borrowing E-Books from the Library
abstract: If your library supports electronic-book lending, you can check out its e-books on an Amazon Kindle.

headline: Wall Street Regulator Ramps Up Enforcement
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, once considered a toothless regulator, brought a record number of enforcement cases over the past year, as fines soared.

headline: Receiving Ashes Before Confronting Afghanistan’s Dust
abstract: A National Guard member packing for deployment to Afghanistan paused for Ash Wednesday services at St. Francis de Sales in New York City, not yet knowing that moments of surprising grace lay before him.

headline: This Week in Small Business: They’re Talking About Us!
abstract: Obama and Romney focus on small business. Unemployment falls. And how to generate word of mouth. Did the debate alter your thinking?

headline: A Quiet Beauty Along the Yangtze
abstract: Nadav Kander spent three years taking photographs along the Yangtze River, producing a set of images that bring beauty to bleak scenes and industrial architecture.

headline: Elliott’s Campaign Against BMC Advances as Company Explores a Sale
abstract: Elliott Management has made strides in its latest activist campaign against a technology company, as BMC Software has retained Bank of America Merrill Lynch to explore a potential sale of itself, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Debating Torture in ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ and a Food Blogger Breaks Out
abstract: Also, a new Google Maps app comes to iPhones, an editor leaves The Times of London, and more.

headline: Happy 80th Birthday, Air India
abstract: Now one of India’s most dilapidated public companies, Air India had a daring, illustrious birth.

headline: PVH to Buy Warnaco Group for $2.9 Billion
abstract: The fashion company PVH Corporation agreed on Wednesday to acquire the Warnaco Group in a $2.9 billion deal, bringing various Calvin Klein brands under one corporate umbrella.

headline: In SAC Capital Case, a New Type of Deal
abstract: The Justice Department’s prosecution of a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors on insider trading charges involved a new tactic – a nonprosecution agreement – to gain the cooperation of a crucial witness.

headline: What the Presidential Candidates Say About Tech
abstract: New York Tech MeetUp, a nonprofit group that represents computer coders and other technology industry people in New York, asked the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates to explain how their policies “would benefit the growth of New York start-up community and other start-up entrepreneurs.”

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
abstract: AMC Networks’ flagship channel, AMC, came back to Dish on Sunday in time for the second episode of the new season of “The Walking Dead.”

abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

abstract: As the Padmini taxi rolls into the sunset, a look back at its Mumbai manufacturer.

headline: A Need for Clearer Disclosure Rules after Cyberattacks
abstract: Regulators need to provide clearer guidance on cyberattack disclosure to help companies address the often competing obligations to law enforcement and their investors, the authors write.

headline: FIAC, Next Stop on the Art-Fair Go-Round
abstract: Art is popping up all over Paris on the eve of the opulent International Contemporary Art Fair, better known as FIAC.

headline: Daily Report: After Apple-HTC Settlement, Other Patent Fights Linger
abstract: Apple has shut down one front in what Steven P. Jobs once described as a thermonuclear legal war against Android, Google’s mobile operating system. But a wider truce in the patent battles engulfing the mobile industry is most likely still a long way off, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: A Conservative Case for the Welfare State
abstract: Conservatives who oppose many social-welfare programs misunderstand both their origin and their efficiency, an economist writes.

headline: In Battle With Hedge Funds, a Small Victory for Argentina
abstract: A stay of a federal judge’s order on debt payment may provide an opportunity for Argentina’s lawyers to raise questions that an appeals court may not have fully considered before.

headline: The Costs of Becoming Disabled
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their experiences with disability insurance.

headline: Adept Moves in Financial Crisis Clear Citigroup Chief’s Path to Top Job
abstract: The new chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, was an all-conference lineman on the Harvard football team and had been head of Citi Holdings, the “bad bank” Citigroup created in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Shares of Freeport Sink as Investors Assail Deals
abstract: Shares of Freeport tumbled more than 13 percent on Wednesday, after the mining concern announced plans to buy two oil and gas explorers, a move that that many investors are rejecting outright.

headline: Delhi Police Deploy Mimes Against Sexual Assault
abstract: A police program attempts to educate people about sex crimes using plays, film screenings and community interactions.

headline: Australian Miner Arrium Rejects $1 Billion Bid by Noble Group and Posco
abstract: The Australian iron ore miner and steel maker Arrium described the takeover approach from a consortium led by the Noble Group and the South Korean steel maker Posco as opportunistic, dismissing it as undervaluing the company.

headline: What Wall Street Is Saying About Citi
abstract: Banking industry analysts give their views on the departure of Vikram Pandit from Citigroup.

headline: The Triumphs and Failures of Deal Makers in 2012
abstract: It was a busy year for Wall Street, and the Deal Professor offers his choices for the best and worst deals of 2012.

headline: Chekhov Again? ‘Uncle Vanya’ and the Instant Replay
abstract: In the British theater a production of one celebrated title by no means precludes another following hot on its heels. Sometimes the one seems almost to be stalking the other. But how much is too much, even of a good thing?

headline: A Tower Pleasing to the Ears and Eyes
abstract: With its sleek, modern design and high-quality sound, the Zikmu Solo speaker tower from Parrot is sure to turn heads.

headline: Gun-Focused Reality TV Shows Get New Scrutiny After Newtown Killings
abstract: A spokeswoman for Discovery Channel said she could not speak definitively about the future, if any, of the popular reality show “Sons of Guns,” which follows life in a custom gun-making company.

headline: Wall St. Wakes Up to a 2nd Obama Term
abstract: Barack Obama’s victory on Tuesday was a complicated moment for the financial industry. | Elizabeth Warren, elected senator from Massachusetts, will be a new wildcard in Washington. | Mitt Romney can always return to a career in high finance, the Deal Professor writes. | BNP Paribas said its profit doubled in the third quarter.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Nov. 1
abstract: News, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Porsche Wins Dismissal of Hedge Fund ‘Short Squeeze’ Lawsuit
abstract: A New York State appeals court dismissed a lawsuit brought by hedge funds against Porsche on Thursday, handing the German automaker a big victory in the long-running legal battle over its attempted takeover of Volkswagen in 2008.

headline: Disruptions: A $1 Billion Start-Up Might Not Be So Fun
abstract: Being in the Billion-Dollar Club limits how, and if, a start-up can get out. For one thing, when you’re the most expensive product on the shelf, very few companies can afford to buy you.

headline: ‘Goat Farmer’ With a Side Project in Advertising Wins ‘Amazing Race’
abstract: Josh Kilmer-Purcell, a creative director at JWT New York, came in first on the show, collecting $1 million, with his fiancé, Brent Ridge. He said he would be moving to live full time at the couple’s farm, which has been the subject of another reality series, “The Fabulous Beekman Boys.”

headline: Mixed Results for S.E.C. in Financial Crisis Cases
abstract: For the Securities and Exchange Commission, proving that an individual broke the law is much more difficult because juries seem to find it much easier to put the blame on the organization while exonerating those who work there.

headline: CNN, Planning New Programming, Hires Jake Tapper From ABC
abstract: Mr. Tapper will be the chief Washington correspondent and the anchor of an afternoon show on the cable news network.

headline: Former Spin Editor to Run BuzzFeed’s Long-Form Coverage
abstract: The site with a knack for items that can spread widely on the Internet has brought in Steve Kandell to oversee its more ambitious journalistic projects.

headline: CareZone, an Anti-Facebook
abstract: Jonathan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Sun Microsystems, says privacy is “something people will pay for.” His start-up, called CareZone, is a way to organize medical records and plan care for the “biological reality” of caring for a child or parent.

headline: Before Breaking a Lease, Check Your Renter’s Policy
abstract: Renter’s insurance may cover the cost of renting elsewhere if your apartment is uninhabitable.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: MSNBC on the Rise, and Judgments on Martha, Conan and Bond
abstract: Also, the National Book Awards has aspirations to become more glamorous and influential; and Valerie Eliot, widow and literary executor of T.S.Eliot, dies at 86.

headline: New Zealand Goes Over the Top Over Middle Earth
abstract: Wellington, the New Zealand capital, is heavily promoting the Nov. 28 premiere of “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” the latest Tolkien film from the director Peter Jackson.

headline: Buyout Funds Lift Carlyle in 3rd Quarter
abstract: In the third quarter, the Carlyle Group’s traditional business of buying and selling companies generated the most growth among the firm’s many funds.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
abstract: What’s on view this week in art museums around the world.

headline: Toyota Industries to Buy Cascade for $759 Million
abstract: Toyota Industries said on Monday that it planned to buy the Cascade Corporation for $759 million in cash as part of its plan to expand globally.

headline: U.S. Sues Wells Fargo, Accusing It of Lying About Mortgages
abstract: Prosecutors accused the bank of lying about the quality of the mortgages it handled under a federal housing program, the latest in a series of lawsuits related to banks’ lending practices during the housing boom.

abstract: News, education, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Monopoly, the Zapped Edition
abstract: Here’s the first entry in the first week of the first year of a new feature: David Pogue’s 12 Gadgets of Christmas. Today’s entry: Monopoly Zapped, a version of the game that lets an iPad or iPhone count the money.

headline: Jobs That You Can Do Forever
abstract: Given that most people don’t have enough money saved to retire at 65, we’ll all need to be thinking about whether we can do our current jobs into our 70s (or whether we need a new career that we could stick with).

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for December
abstract: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 3
abstract: International Day of Persons with Disabilities observed in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Dropping the Ball on Financial Regulation
abstract: The opportunity to choose strong reformers to head key agencies may yield to the goal of pleasing prominent people in the financial sector, an economist writes.

headline: Raikkonen, A Real Human Among the F1 Automatons
abstract: Kimi Raikkonen has truly returned after two years away from Formula One, winning the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. The big story on Sunday was the reduction of the championship contenders to just two, but Raikkonen’s sharp tongue provided the most entertaining story.

headline: Daily Report: For Japan’s Electronics Behemoths, Dire Times Ahead
abstract: Three of Japan’s consumer electronics giants — Sharp, Panasonic and Sony — are showing signs of faltering, reports Hiroko Tabuchi in Friday’s New York Times.

headline: Diageo and United Spirits Finally Reach a Deal
abstract: World’s largest spirits company expected to take majority stake in Indian company.

abstract: Two recent deals — one involving Starbucks and the other Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold — illustrate how a transaction can be structured to avoid a shareholder vote.

headline: What Obama Will Do Now in Iran, Syria, China — and Congress
abstract: Barack Obama has to contend with the Republican majority returning to the House of Representatives and foreign policy challenges from Iran to China.

headline: Glencore Offers Concessions to Win Support for Xstrata Deal
abstract: Glencore International has offered concessions to European antitrust authorities in a bid to win support for its $33 billion proposed takeover of the mining company Xstrata.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Prank Packs
abstract: Fool your gift recipients into thinking they got some horrible tech gift with Prank Panks, suggests David Pogue.

headline: Updates From Apple’s Product Event
abstract: Apple unveiled a smaller iPad, a new iMac and other revamped products at an event at the California Theater in San Jose, Calif.

headline: NBC Pulls the Plug on ‘Animal Practice’
abstract: The new sitcom will be replaced in the Wednesday lineup with the second-year sitcom “Whitney.”

headline: Putin vs. the European Competition Commission
abstract: As Gazprom and a European Union commission go head to head over the Russian gas giant’s aggressive moves in Eastern Europe, Russia may miss an opportunity to help itself.

headline: Liquor Baron’s Death Opens Market in Uttar Pradesh
abstract: Ponty Chadha had a virtual monopoly on liquor trade in the state.

headline: For Bravo Start-Ups Show, Crash Test Dummies
abstract: In Silicon Valley, which day-to-day can be quite a boring place, Bravo’s new reality show, “Start-Ups: Silicon Valley,” has had to manufacture something that doesn’t really exist here: drama.

headline: IPhone 5 May Burn Through Excessive Cell Data on Verizon
abstract: Owners of Apple’s new iPhone 5 may notice that the phone is guzzling more bytes over the cellular network on Verizon Wireless than it should, which could lead to a hefty bill. It turns out there’s a bug.

headline: To Add Flights to Heathrow, Delta Buys 49% Stake in Virgin Atlantic
abstract: Delta, which paid $360 million for the stake, wants more access to Heathrow Airport in London, one of the world’s busiest hubs, where takeoff and landing rights are limited because of high demand and tight capacity.

headline: A Global Shift in Foreign Aid, Starting in India
abstract: Britain’s decision to cut aid to India after decades comes as developed countries worldwide rethink what they give.

headline: What Next for Netflix?
abstract: Carl C. Icahn will probably push for a sale of Netflix, but this may turn out to be a replay of the Air Products bid for Airgas, where a board just says no, even if a bidder emerges — and even if shareholders want a sale to happen.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Thursday, Oct. 25
abstract: News, education and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: Thiel Fund Leads Investment in Brazilian Start-Up
abstract: Peter Thiel’s Valar Ventures Management has made its first foray in Brazil, leading an investment in an e-commerce start-up that is trying to shake up the traditional furniture market here and take on an established retailer recently acquired by the Carlyle Group.

headline: Facebook Says Child Privacy Laws Should Not Apply to ‘Like’ Buttons
abstract: Child privacy laws collide with the First Amendment, Facebook says, as the Federal Trade Commission proposes to revise a law limiting Web sites’ ability to collect information on children.

headline: Cedar Lake Ballet Makes a Brief, Well-Chosen Stop at Sadler’s Wells
abstract: When Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded in New York in 2003 by the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie, it was generally regarded in the dance world as a rich woman’s folly. So much for the naysayers: The company has developed a reputation as the purveyor of new and interesting European choreography.

headline: Reflections on the Third Anniversary of My Pink Slip
abstract: A student in an M.B.A. class recently asked me what my five-year plan was. I wanted to answer that it was to try to make payroll next week.

headline: More Often These Days, the Director Is a She
abstract: The British stage as male preserve now seems a thing of the past.

headline: Deutsche Bank Posts $975 Million Profit in Third Quarter
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest lender, said its third-quarter profit declined 3 percent, as a surge in investment banking revenue offset costs related to the firm’s legal problems and a cost-cutting program.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Sound Oasis Sound Therapy Pillow
abstract: A pillow with speakers inside — just what Santa ordered. Day 6 in Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets.

headline: After a Quarterly Gain, Pandora Warns of a Loss to Come
abstract: Pandora Media reported $120 million in third-quarter revenue, up 60 percent, but said it expected a fourth-quarter loss. Its stock dropped 18 percent after hours.

headline: Universities Ponder Accounting 101: How to Balance the Books
abstract: Should universities be government-funded basic services, like roads and hospitals? Or should they be market driven? If so, will only big-name, elite schools draw moneyed donors and rich students?

headline: Thanksgiving’s Hispanic Roots, America’s Hispanic Future
abstract: For most Americans, Thanksgiving recalls the Pilgrims and Plymouth Rock. A rival claim says the first Thanksgiving was hosted in Florida by the Spanish. On the verge of the 500th anniversary of the discovery of North America by Ponce de Leon, Spain challenges the Anglos’ for their rightful place in American history.

headline: Image of the Day: Nov. 23
abstract: A procession to mark Muharram, the first month of the Islamic calendar, in Amroha, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: For Children, a Lie on Facebook Has Consequences, Study Finds
abstract: Highlighting how difficult it is to regulate children’s privacy, a new academic study shows that in an unnamed American high school, a few children who lied about their ages to get Facebook accounts could unwittingly allow a stranger to learn about other children at the school.

headline: Modi Inches Closer to India’s Capital
abstract: Narendra Modi’s win in the Gujarat elections could lead to a prime minister nomination in 2014.

headline: Fighting to Get Women in the Boardroom
abstract: Viviane Reding, vice president of the European Commission, is pressing the case to mandate quotas for women on boards of European companies despite strong resistance. Liz Alderman of the International Herald Tribune interviewed her at the Women’s Forum for the Economy and Society in Deauville, France.

headline: A Social Business Strikes a Deal With Big Tobacco
abstract: Consumers can create a collection location at no cost by signing up a home or business on our Web site. We pay the shipping, and for each pound of cigarette waste collected, we donate $1 to Keep America Beautiful.

headline: Q&A: Running Windows XP, Virtually
abstract: You can still run old Windows XP programs on a new Windows 7 PC with tools from Microsoft.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.

headline: Roger Ailes Signs Up for Another 4 Years at Fox News
abstract: Mr. Ailes will remain in charge of the Fox News Channel, the News Corporation said on Friday, ending a protracted period of speculation about his contract negotiations.

headline: Fact-Checking the F.D.I. Debates, Part 2
abstract: Will allowing foreign retail into India actually create four million jobs?

headline: Using Crowdfunding to Start a Company With a Cause
abstract: For Kara Gorski and Kristin Gembala, starting a company to manufacture bras for breast-cancer survivors was more than just business.

abstract: If you want to delete an app you installed from the Chrome Web Store, you can remove it right in Chrome.

abstract: Traditional recipes with an Indian twist.

abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. abstract: The average consumer spends about $35 on a live Christmas tree. Ann Carrns defends her $100 purchase.

headline: Study May Offer Insight Into Coca-Cola Breach
abstract: A 2010 case study of a security breach at an unnamed Fortune 500 company appears to offers new details of a breach at Coca-Cola.

headline: Week in Review: Ex-Goldman Trader’s Book Is Short on Details
abstract: Greg Smith’s book offered few details on Goldman. | Rajat K. Gupta’s lawyers pushed for leniency. | N.Y.U. Law announced an overhaul. | Vikram Pandit stepped down after Citi’s chairman stepped up. | Andrew Ross Sorkin said nowadays, Wall St. saviors may wish they weren’t.

headline: As India Responds to Latest Rapes, the Unanswered Question is ‘Why?’
abstract: Are the uneducated new rich, caste conflict, or government to blame? Social scientists, activists and politicians weigh in.

headline: At Delhi Protest Ground, Talk of Causes Behind Violence Against Women
abstract: Men spoke of frustration and economic disparity, while women said mothers should teach children better.

headline: In Kerala, Political Humor is Embraced
abstract: Politicians tolerate, and even welcome, the southern state’s tradition of sharp satire.

abstract: As the city struggles to come back online in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, New York start-ups and companies get creative about going back to work.

abstract: The company and the guild have been engaged in protracted negotiations over issue mainly involving pension, salaries and health insurance.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: Tagg Pet Tracker
abstract: On the seventh day, David Pogue’s gift goes to the dogs: the Tagg Pet Tracker.

abstract: Aakash is a “politically-charged project people take glee in demeaning.”

abstract: Lone gunman in attacks that left over 160 dead was hung in Pune.

abstract: Michael O’Neill is one of a new generation of board members unwilling to cede too much power to chief executives.

abstract: Besides the stake taken, Allied World will invest $500 million in MatlinPatterson’s funds, a pattern seen in recent acquisitions by other institutional investors.

abstract: McGraw-Hill agreed on Monday to sell its education division to Apollo Global Management for about $2.5 billion, completing the publisher’s transformation into a provider of high-end financial information.

headline: Facebook and Google Benefit From Mobile Ad Surge
abstract: Making big money from advertisements on a small screen has been a challenge for many media companies, including Facebook and Google. But mobile ad spending grew significantly this past year, according to a new report.

abstract: The buyout firm Advent International has offered to buy the German retailer Douglas Holding for about $1.9 billion.

headline: Relief and Hope in Asia Over Obama Victory
abstract: Continuity with another four years of Barack Obama, rather than a jump into the relative unknown with his challenger, is what many people appeared to prefer. Still, there was also a sense of guarded anticipation on Wednesday, as analysts, commentators and the financial markets took stock of the daunting economic that the administration faces as well as the foreign policy issues that are closest to Asia’s heart.

abstract: In a public letter released on Tuesday, Mike Lynch again rejected Hewlett-Packard’s claims about Autonomy, arguing that H.P. botched its takeover of his former company and mishandled its integration.

abstract: Evidence suggests that Steven A. Cohen participated in trades that the government says illegally used insider information, but he has not been charged.

abstract: The latest shake-ups at newspaper companies. Marketing to single aunts. Networks fail to produce fall television hits.

abstract: Policymakers are unsure of the impact of more stimulus on the slowly recovering British economy, minutes of their latest talks show.

abstract: Li Jianli, the man who was attacked in the provincial capital of Xi’an for driving a Japanese-made car during anti-Japan protests last month, has withdrawn a lawsuit against the police.

abstract: Weak earnings from several large companies and a credit rating downgrade of several regions in Spain raised concerns about a slowing global economy.

abstract: While not unexpected, the revocation by the Chinese Catholic Bishops Council is likely to aggravate tensions between Beijing and the Vatican.

abstract: Angered by President Mohamed Morsi’s hurried effort to pass Egypt’s new constitution, tens of thousands of people streamed into Tahrir Square.

abstract: Chen Kegui was convicted for injuring a government official who broke into his home looking for his uncle, the human rights lawyer Chen Guangcheng.

abstract: An environmental organization said that China has ignored the trade of illegally harvested lumber across its borders.

abstract: Jalal Talabani was said to be in “stable” condition after he suffered a stroke earlier this week.

abstract: Inam Ur Raheem, who has challenged the tenure of Pakistan’s supreme military commander, has entered perilous waters at a time when the military leadership’s longstanding grip on power is being tested.

abstract: The top leader of Hamas dared Israel on Monday to launch a ground invasion of Gaza and dismissed efforts to broker a cease-fire as Israel conducted a new wave of deadly airstrikes.

abstract: The anniversary of the Luxembourg Agreement was observed in Berlin as the government reaffirmed its duty to continue paying reparations to Hitler’s victims.

abstract: The government said Tuesday that it would clarify its abortion policy by the end of the year after publishing a long-overdue report on an issue that has divided the country

abstract: The Constitutional Council opposed a plan to impose a 75 percent marginal income tax rate on the wealthy that would have applied to annual income above 1 million euros, or about $1.3 million.

abstract: In split-second auctions, companies are jockeying for the chance to buy online ads geared to your specific tastes. But consumer advocates see a risk of a computer-generated class system.

abstract: In a male-dominated society, Andalib Adwan Shehada has challenged attitudes toward abuse, rape, honor killing and divorce.

abstract: The global decline in monthly sales during October represents the fast-food chain’s first such dip in nearly a decade.

abstract: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.

abstract: “There is nothing to suggest that I acted inappropriately,” said Mark Thompson, the former BBC director general and incoming chief executive of The New York Times Company.

abstract: Suzuki is strong in emerging markets, but has long had weak sales in the United States, where it will now stop selling its automobiles.

abstract: The leader of Britain's biggest business lobby on Monday issued a stark warning of the growing risk that the country would leave the European Union.

abstract: Steve McMichael is a stunt coordinator for the film and television industry. He enjoys flying less than he used to.

abstract: A proposal to limit tax deductions might be politically popular, but it is not the evenhanded approach to closing loopholes it appears to be.
