headline: Church’s Muscle Helped Propel President’s Rivals to Victory in Georgia
abstract: The elections brought an end to the eight-year dominance of President Mikheil Saakashvili and his team, and their push to introduce Western ways to this conservative society.

headline: U.N. Says Execution Video From Syria Shows Apparent War Crime
abstract: A new video that seems to show Syrian rebels summarily executing a group of captured soldiers or militiamen could, if verified, represent evidence of a war crime, the United Nations said on Friday.

headline: Hurricane Helps to Lift Auto Sales to 4-Year High
abstract: Replacement of cars and trucks damaged in Hurricane Sandy contributed to the industry’s best monthly pace since 2008.

headline: Chinese Court Said to Punish Tibetan Students with Prison Terms
abstract: The International Campaign for Tibet said that eight Tibetan students were sentenced to five-year terms for their role in street protests last month during a wave of self-immolations.

headline: U.N. Vote Planned on Mali Security
abstract: A United Nations Security Council resolution would approve the deployment of a multinational African force in Mali to help retake the northern part of the country from Islamist militias.

headline: From H.P., a Blunder That Seems to Beat All
abstract: It seemed likely that a deal like AOL’s acquisition of Time Warner would never be repeated, rivaled or surpassed, but the deal for Autonomy may qualify.

headline: In a German Town, Court Finds That Mayor Cried Wolf
abstract: A district court found that Norbert Moosmann, of the Black Forest town of Rickenbach, had staged the throwing of an empty Molotov cocktail into his office.

headline: In China Protests, Japanese Car Sales Suffer
abstract: Japanese automakers have cut manufacturing by up to half in China after violent anti-Japanese protests over disputed islands in which Japanese-brand cars and even their owners were targeted.

headline: E.E.O.C. Finds Race Bias in Firing at Wet Seal Store
abstract: The commission said Wet Seal managers “stated they wanted employees who had the ‘Armani look, were white, had blue eyes, thin and blond in order to be profitable.’ ”

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
abstract: Software consulting is a multibillion-dollar business, and the means by which most enterprise software actually ends up in business. Consultants figure out what companies need, install it, customize it, and train workers on it. As more software is sold over the cloud, consulting is changing too, stressing more collaboration.

headline: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
abstract: AMC Networks’ flagship channel, AMC, came back to Dish on Sunday in time for the second episode of the new season of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: The Man Who Sparked Bollywood’s Love of Foreign Locales
abstract: Filmmaker Yash Chopra, who died on Sunday, brought the mountains of Switzerland and the tulips of the Netherlands to millions of fans.

headline: Outside India, Shankar Fascinated Generations of Fans
abstract: Coverage of Ravi Shankar in the New York Times spanned six decades.

headline: Review of Reviews: The Surface
abstract: Here is what other tech product reviewers thought of the Microsoft Surface.

headline: Oracle: Big Business Has Big Data Woes
abstract: On the eve of one of the tech industry’s biggest corporate shows, Oracle OpenWorld, Mark Hurd, Oracle’s co-president, talked about some of the trends troubling business today, and what Oracle was doing about them. Data is choking business, and the software industry is not ready, he says.

headline: Scotland’s Mexican Drug Connection
abstract: “You’ve just come from Mexico? Well, you’ll be wanting some cocaine then,” my new Scottish friend joked. “We’ve got loads of it here in the Highlands.”

headline: Orient-Express Rejects Takeover Bid and Names New Chief
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels formally rejected an unsolicited takeover bid by an arm of the Tata Group of India, criticizing it as undervalued and ill timed. It also named a new chief executive, John M. Scott, who would replace the company’s outgoing leader.

headline: Big Spaces for Big Art at the Edges of Paris
abstract: An area on the Île Seguin will be among the sites for FIAC, the mid-October Paris art fair. The space, called R4, will eventually become a Jean Nouvel-designed complex. It is only one of several new art spaces on the Paris periphery.

headline: The Trust Women Conference
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and ThomsonReuters Foundation will host a gathering on Tuesday and Wednesday to examine how law can be used to further the empowerment of women. Watch the streaming video starting at 10 a.m. London time on Tuesday. Read our preview stories now.

headline: U.S. Envoy Optimistic About Ties With China
abstract: Gary F. Locke, the United States ambassador to China, spoke at a sold-out forum in which he said both countries had become inextricably linked to each other economically.

headline: Report Raises Concerns Over St. Jude Heart Device
abstract: A report by the Food and Drug Administration found flaws in the company’s testing and oversight of a product known as the Durata.

headline: Iran Tests New Version of Missiles in Exercise
abstract: A wide-ranging naval exercise focused on striking hypothetical unmanned aircraft and vessels in international waters to the south of the country.

headline: Business Owners Tally the Storm Damage and Ponder Its Lessons
abstract: With their inventory and equipment damaged by seawater and lack of power and many of their employees absent, small-business owners struggled to recover.

headline: On This, 2 Sides Agree: Fighting Hardened Positions
abstract: The eight days of fighting between Hamas and Israel have left more than 160 people dead, and have dimmed hopes for reviving an already-moribund peace process.

headline: A Proliferation of Ways to Use a Tax Break as Its End Nears
abstract: Time is running out on a generous exemption from gift taxes, but tax advisers have no shortage of ways to get in under the deadline.

headline: Horrific Fire Revealed a Gap in Safety for Global Brands
abstract: A blaze that killed 112 workers in Bangladesh last month exposed a disconnect among retailers like Sears and Walmart, the monitoring system to protect workers and the factories filling the orders.

headline: With Help, Afghan Survivor of ‘Honor Killing’ Inches Back
abstract: The story of Gul Meena, who was accused of adultery and struck by an ax 15 times, is also the story of a society struggling with shifting attitudes about women.

headline: 总理家人隐秘的财富
abstract: This is a Chinese-language version of an investigation by The New York Times showing that the family of Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, owns about $2.7 billion in assets.

headline: Taliban Reiterate Vow to Kill Pakistani Girl
abstract: The Pakistan police said they had made several arrests in the shooting of the teenage education activist Malala Yousafzai, but the Taliban said she would be targeted again.

headline: Naval Patrols to Expel Ships in South China Sea
abstract: Chinese naval patrols have been authorized to search and repel ships that “illegally enter” an area in the South China Sea through which much of the region’s commercial vessels pass.

headline: For Solar Panel Industry, a Volley of Trade Cases
abstract: The United States and Europe have accused Chinese solar panel manufacturers of benefiting from government subsidies.

headline: Japan’s New Leader Endorses Nuclear Plants
abstract: Shinzo Abe, the newly elected prime minister, said Sunday that he would seek to build nuclear reactors, reversing a campaign pledge to move Japan away from nuclear power.

headline: West Is Foolish to Celebrate Iran’s Rial Crisis, Ayatollah Says
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, dismissed last week’s protest over the country’s plummeting currency as an anomaly that the West had misinterpreted as a harbinger of crisis.

headline: How Wal-Mart Used Payoffs to Get Its Way in Mexico
abstract: Wal-Mart de Mexico was an aggressive and creative corrupter, offering large payoffs to get what the law otherwise prohibited, an examination by The New York Times found.

headline: Bloomberg Weighs Making Bid for The Financial Times
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, who has an affinity for The Financial Times, is said to be weighing the wisdom of buying the newspaper if it is put up for sale by Pearson.

headline: At 20, Holocaust Museum Plans a Call to Action
abstract: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum has already begun to observe its 20th anniversary and has hired agencyEA in Chicago to run its education and memorial tours next year.

headline: Insurers Estimate $10 Billion in Damages
abstract: The insurance industry could end up paying out $5 billion to $10 billion in covered losses on Sandy.

headline: Piggybacking on Black Friday
abstract: Typically a retail event, Black Friday has drawn marketers from other domains into the fray.

headline: China Stalls Move to Quell Asia Disputes Over Territory
abstract: Representatives of members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations take issue with a Cambodian statement on resolving disputes in the South China Sea.

headline: Israel Defies Allies in Move to Bolster Settlements
abstract: Brushing aside a growing chorus of international opposition, Israel pushed ahead with aggressive new settlement building in the West Bank and Jerusalem on Wednesday.

headline: Watching U.S. Race, Other Nations See Themselves
abstract: How other countries have covered the race often tells as much about how they feel about themselves as it does about how they perceive the American political process.

headline: Governors Promote Lower Deductibles for Homeowners
abstract: Homeowners who suffered wind and storm damage this week will get financial relief from rulings that insurers must treat Sandy as a tropical storm and not a hurricane.

headline: The Fiscal Stimulus, Flawed but Valuable
abstract: The 2009 Recovery Act improved the lives of many Americans, but it would have benefited from an extra, Rooseveltian kick, an economist says.

headline: Facebook Cancels Shortcut Over Concern for Security
abstract: What was supposed to be a shortcut for Facebook users to log into their pages ended up exposing their e-mail addresses, potentially allowing access to their accounts as well.

headline: As Microsoft Shifts Its Privacy Rules, an Uproar Is Absent
abstract: The difference in reactions to broader gathering and use of users’ data at Google and at Microsoft illustrates the confusion around Internet consumer privacy.

headline: For Syria’s Rebel Movement, Skype Is a Useful and Increasingly Dangerous Tool
abstract: Using satellite technology, much of it smuggled in, activists are still communicating online during an Internet blackout that started Thursday, but the government is finding ways to listen.

headline: Winter’s Approach Adds to Crisis as Refugee Population Swells
abstract: The population of registered war refugees in Syria’s neighboring countries is expected to nearly double by year’s end, to more than 700,000 people, just as the winter approaches.

headline: Libya Attack Shows Pentagon’s Limits in Region
abstract: The Pentagon’s Africa Command, based in Germany, lacked a quick-response force to send to Libya when American diplomatic posts came under attack in Benghazi.

headline: Peugeot Wins Promise of State Aid and Announces Pact With G.M.
abstract: The struggling French automaker PSA Peugeot Citroën will obtain $9 billion in government credit guarantees and will cooperate with the General Motors unit Opel on four vehicle projects.

headline: Among Americans in Israel, More Forceful Backing for Romney
abstract: Perhaps as a response to lobbying efforts, over twice as many Americans living in Israel voted by absentee ballot this week as in 2008, and according to surveys, two-thirds of them chose Romney.

headline: Ethnic Tension Drives Russian Crackdown on Rubber-Bullet Guns
abstract: Authorities are pursuing more cases involving handguns that fire rubber bullets out of concern that they are primarily being bought by migrants from the former Soviet republics.

headline: Putin, in Need of Cohesion, Pushes Patriotism
abstract: Vladimir Putin, a ruthless pragmatist, is facing a problem he has never encountered: the need for an ideology.

headline: Warning Issued on Alternative Hip Replacement Procedure
abstract: A study published in The Lancet found that women experienced “unacceptably high” failure rates with the technique used instead of traditional hip implants. Some men were also affected.

headline: Firms Don’t Share Consumer Optimism
abstract: Many bellwether businesses have reported disappointing results and cut their outlook for future growth, but consumers remain buoyant.

headline: Rebuilding in Haiti Lags After Billions in Post-Quake Aid
abstract: Despite billions of dollars spent — and billions more allocated for Haiti but unspent — rebuilding has barely begun and 357,785 Haitians still languish in 496 tent camps.

headline: A Little Perspective Can Open Eyes
abstract: Dan Bailey and Phelps, his guide dog, are serene in the midst of travel chaos.

headline: Real and Virtual Firearms Nurture a Marketing Link
abstract: The makers of firearms and the producers of violent video games have quietly forged a mutually beneficial marketing relationship.

abstract: Raghuram G. Rajan’s calls for widespread and speedy changes to the nation’s economy are being heard by his boss, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh.

abstract: Three sleek and shiny PCs from Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Vizio offer the latest components but no DVD drives.

abstract: Consumers and businesses spend billions of dollars a year on antivirus software, but these programs rarely block freshly minted strains, because the malware creators move too fast.

abstract: As 2013 approaches, an update on some topics from 2012: the success of “The Voice,” a North Carolina businessman’s stand for gay marriage and whither Apple?

headline: William Blair, Reporter and Executive for Times, Dies at 87
abstract: In his early years at The Times, Mr. Blair reported on both local and national news. He also worked in the United Nations bureau before becoming a foreign correspondent in 1956.

headline: BBC Episode Examines Its Own Sex Scandal
abstract: In response to an uproar over its mishandling of sexual abuse allegations, the British Broadcasting Corporation aired a highly self-critical examination.

headline: Mythic Salamander Faces Crucial Test: Survival in the Wild
abstract: The decline of the axolotl in the wild has been precipitous, and its extinction would end one of the few natural links Mexicans still have with the city that the Aztecs built.

headline: Fiscal Cutoff Would Pinch at First, Then Get Steadily Worse
abstract: After hopes for a bargain to avoid hundreds of billions of dollars in tax increases and spending cuts have faded, economists are giving odds on what will happen and when, and its effect on a tender recovery.

headline: Toxic Cough Syrup Kills 16 Pakistanis
abstract: The dead were between 20 and 45 years old, and a homicide investigation was opened involving the factory that made the syrup.

headline: Iran’s Fordo Nuclear Complex Reaches Capacity
abstract: Iran has finished installing equipment at an underground site where it is producing nuclear fuel that could quickly be converted to use in a nuclear weapon, international inspectors reported on Friday.

headline: South Korean Official Warns of ‘Existential Threat’ From North
abstract: A senior South Korean policy maker said on Friday that it must be assumed that Pyongyang has the capacity to mount a nuclear device on a ballistic missile.

headline: Showing Off a Tablet’s Graphical Powers, Android Style
abstract: Google now offers a number of apps that display the capabilities of Android-based tablets.

headline: Afghan Artist, Admired Around the World, Yearns for Acceptance at Home
abstract: Paintings by Abdul Wasi Hamdard can be found in every corner of the world, but as foreigners leave Kabul, the market for his work — and his drive to create it — has dried up.

headline: Arthur Chaskalson, Chief South African Jurist, Dies at 81
abstract: Justice Chaskalson was the first presiding judge of the post-apartheid Constitutional Court and served as chief justice from 2001 to 2005.

headline: At Ad Week, the Vital Role of Digital Marketing
abstract: Each year, Advertising Week in New York becomes more fundamentally about the role of digital, mobile and social media in selling goods and services.

headline: Spain’s Troubles Catch Up With a Storied Newspaper
abstract: Journalists at El País held a two-hour work stoppage after management announced plans to dismiss one-third of the staff.

headline: Symbol of Romanian Leadership? Hands on a Throat
abstract: Perhaps the best that can be said of relations between the president and prime minister of Romania is that they are unambiguous: they can’t stand each other.

abstract: As the war drags on, some people of Syrian descent, from the United States and other Western countries, have traveled to Syria to help in the fight against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Mexico: Top Mob Prosecutor Resigns
abstract: José Cuitláhuac Salinas, the nation’s top organized crime prosecutor abruptly resigned Thursday.

headline: Dueling Prisms for Valuing Stocks
abstract: Stock valuation can be more accurate when averaged over 10 years, but significant anomalies, like the great recession, may throw off the numbers.

headline: Housing Move in Israel Seen as Setback for a Two-State Plan
abstract: Two settlement actions seemed timed to punish the Palestinians for securing upgraded status at the United Nations, and appeared to show that hard-liners had prevailed in the debate over a response.

headline: Some Analysts Doubt Dire Predictions on Tax Increase Fallout
abstract: Judging from tax changes in the past, some economists see a mostly mild effect on markets if tax rates on dividends and capital gains rise at the end of the year, as the White House has proposed.

abstract: Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz  appeared on television to call for calm on Sunday, hours after being shot by soldiers in what he said was an accident.

abstract: Secretary of Defense Leon E. Panetta and Gen. Martin E. Dempsey said they would strictly enforce standards for their most senior officers.

abstract: Once the hottest new thing on Wall Street, lightning-quick computerized trading is expected to make less money this year, with profits down 35 percent from last year.

abstract: The owners of Big Sandy, a coal-fired facility in eastern Kentucky, said it was too expensive to retrofit the plant to conform to new environmental rules.

headline: Print’s Poetry Still a Draw for the Publisher Felix Dennis
abstract: The magazine publisher, who took America by storm in the 1990s with Maxim, still revels in the print business and prides himself on knowing what readers want.

abstract: Analysts say the 14th straight day of patrols in the East China Sea suggests China is trying to wear down Japan’s resolve.

abstract: The chief executive of XOJet describes the unexpected job that led him to many years of working in the technology field.

abstract: A comic’s heart beats inside Dick Costolo, the nonconforming chief executive of Twitter who may well hold the key to the company’s success.

abstract: Former President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo was arrested Thursday on corruption charges related to the suspected misuse of state lottery funds during her administration.

abstract: The explosion killed one person and damaged the headquarters of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent relief organization, state media reported.

headline: Suit Exposes Strict Manual for Abercrombie Flight Crew
abstract: The Abercrombie & Fitch chief’s instructions for the corporate jet team ranged from acceptable responses to questions to where precisely his dogs would sit.

abstract: The heads of the European Union's member states appeared to be taking advantage of the relative calm in markets to put off more moves toward integration.

headline: Simpler Taxes Now, Growth Later
abstract: Economists say the talk in Washington of raising additional tax revenue and cutting spending would most likely depress growth in the short term.

abstract: Despite rising controversy over their prominent role, China’s princelings are emerging as a class that has an increasingly important say in ruling the country.

abstract: The world’s third-largest cocaine producer has taken an unorthodox approach to controlling the growing of coca that veers markedly from the wider war on narcotics.

abstract: Heavy shelling and gunfire on Monday broke a tense standoff between Congolese rebels on the outskirts of the eastern city of Goma and government soldiers backed by United Nations troops.

abstract: Vladimir Markin, the spokesman for the federal Investigative Committee, said the attack appeared to be “a warning to other journalists” involved in news coverage about the government’s campaign against insurgents.

abstract: Leonid Razvozzhayev was held in a basement and denied food and water for more than two days, human rights officials said.

abstract: Consumer confidence fell sharply in the first half of December despite improvement in new home sales and a slight drop in new jobless claims.

abstract: With Israeli elections scheduled for January, the situation is likely to get tougher for the Palestinians before it gets better.

abstract: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal belt tape confessions and executions of men accused of aiding drone attacks, deepening an atmosphere of paranoia and mistrust.

abstract: William Christie, the founder of a Baroque orchestra, opened his extraordinary garden in Thiré, France, for a music festival this August.

abstract: The remarks by Chris Patten, the head of the supervisory BBC Trust, and Tim Davie, the acting director general, came as they were addressing a parliamentary panel.

abstract: Intelligence officials believe network attacks that crippled computers across the Saudi oil industry and breached American financial institutions originated in Iran.

abstract: Businesses in the Northeast are trying to keep operations running after Hurricane Sandy knocked out power and transportation in many areas.

abstract: New research to be published in the journal Science suggests that radioactive particles from last year’s nuclear disaster have accumulated on the sea floor and could contaminate sea life for decades.

headline: Google Casts a Big Shadow on Smaller Web Sites
abstract: For Web sites that depend on their ranking in search results, Google’s secret — and frequently fluctuating — search algorithm can evoke a complex blend of admiration and fear.

headline: Grabs for Power Behind Plan to Shrink Elite Circle
abstract: A proposal by Chinese leaders to downsize the powerful Politburo Standing Committee offers one of the clearest windows available into the intentions of the Communist Party.

abstract: Just one of 23 Afghan brigades is able to operate on its own without air or other military support from the United States or NATO, a report found.

headline: In Dairy Industry Consolidation, Lush Paydays
abstract: Through certain deals, huge paychecks went to a small group of people, including the chief executive of Dean Foods and a former head of a dairy cooperative.

abstract: Officials have said the “obvious suspicion” is that at least some of the apparent growth in gold shipments to Dubai is tied to illicit activities that have come to define Afghanistan’s economy.

abstract: An officer for the Central Intelligence Agency was killed on Saturday in a suicide bombing in southern Afghanistan, American officials said Tuesday.

abstract: A bomb was found under the car of Hamid Mir, who hosts one of Pakistan’s most-watched political talk shows.

abstract: Karl Heiselman, the head of Wolff Olins, a brand consulting firm, says job candidates’ sincerity about their goals can be more important than whether they are an exact fit for the position.

abstract: For the first time in a decade, rebels and the government of Colombia came together with the goal of ending the longest-running war in the Western Hemisphere.

abstract: Vladimir Strzhalkovsky, chief executive of Norilsk Nickel and an ally of President Vladimir Putin, stepped down as part of the settlement of a shareholder dispute.

abstract: Spain announced that it would grant automatic citizenship to Jews of Sephardic descent as a further gesture of reconciliation after their ancestors were expelled more than five centuries ago.

abstract: A flood of applicants for examinations to fill teaching positions said as much about Italy’s dim job prospects as it did about the rigidities of its public education system.

abstract: A Web site, Rent the Runway, is offering women the opportunity to see someone their age and size in expensive clothing before renting it.

headline: China: Tibetan Monk Kills Himself in Fiery Protest
abstract: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China killed himself by setting himself on fire Monday evening to protest Chinese rule, an advocacy group said.
